**Charlemagne** ([/ˈʃɑːrlɪmeɪn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"))
or **Charles the Great**[a] (2 April 742[1][b] – 28 January 814), numbered
**Charles I** , was [King of the Franks](/wiki/King_of_the_Franks "King of the
Franks") from 768, [King of the Lombards](/wiki/King_of_the_Lombards "King of
the Lombards") from 774 and [Emperor of the Romans](/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor
"Holy Roman Emperor") from 800. He united much of Europe during the early
[Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"). He was the first recognised
emperor in western Europe since the [fall of the Western Roman
Empire](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire "Fall of the Western Roman
Empire") three centuries earlier. The expanded Frankish state that Charlemagne
founded is called the [Carolingian Empire](/wiki/Carolingian_Empire
"Carolingian Empire").

Charlemagne was the oldest son of [Pepin the Short](/wiki/Pepin_the_Short
"Pepin the Short") and [Bertrada of Laon](/wiki/Bertrada_of_Laon "Bertrada of
Laon"), having been born before their canonical marriage.[2] He became king in
768 following his father's death, initially as co-ruler with his brother
[Carloman I](/wiki/Carloman_I_of_the_Franks "Carloman I of the Franks").
Carloman's sudden death in December 771 under unexplained circumstances left
Charlemagne as the sole, undisputed ruler of the Frankish Kingdom.[3] He
continued his father's policy towards the [papacy](/wiki/Pope "Pope") and
became its protector, removing the [Lombards](/wiki/Lombards "Lombards") from
power in northern Italy and leading an incursion into [Muslim Spain](/wiki/Al-
Andalus "Al-Andalus"). He campaigned against the [Saxons](/wiki/Saxons
"Saxons") to his east, [Christianising them upon penalty of
death](/wiki/Capitulatio_de_partibus_Saxoniae "Capitulatio de partibus
Saxoniae") and leading to events such as the [Massacre of
Verden](/wiki/Massacre_of_Verden "Massacre of Verden"). Charlemagne reached
the height of his power in 800 when he was [crowned _Emperor of the
Romans_](/wiki/Coronation_of_the_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Coronation of the Holy
Roman Emperor") by [Pope Leo III](/wiki/Pope_Leo_III "Pope Leo III") on
Christmas Day at Rome's [Old St. Peter's
Basilica](/wiki/Old_St._Peter%27s_Basilica "Old St. Peter's Basilica").

Charlemagne has been called the "Father of Europe" (_Pater Europae_),[c] as he
united most of Western Europe for the first time since the [Roman
Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"). His rule spurred the [Carolingian
Renaissance](/wiki/Carolingian_Renaissance "Carolingian Renaissance"), a
period of energetic cultural and intellectual activity within the Western
Church. All [Holy Roman Emperors](/wiki/List_of_Holy_Roman_Emperors "List of
Holy Roman Emperors") considered their kingdoms to be descendants of
Charlemagne's empire, up to the last [Emperor Francis
II](/wiki/Francis_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor") and
the [French](/wiki/List_of_French_monarchs "List of French monarchs") and
[German](/wiki/List_of_German_monarchs "List of German monarchs")
monarchies.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

However, the [Eastern Orthodox Church](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern
Orthodox Church") views Charlemagne more controversially, labeling as
[heterodox](/wiki/Heterodoxy "Heterodoxy") his support of the
[filioque](/wiki/Filioque "Filioque") and recognition by the [Bishop of
Rome](/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome "Bishop of Rome") as legitimate Roman Emperor,
rather than recognising [Irene of Athens](/wiki/Irene_of_Athens "Irene of
Athens") of the [Eastern Roman Empire](/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire "Eastern
Roman Empire"). These and other machinations led to the eventual split of Rome
and Constantinople in the [Great Schism of
1054](/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism "East–West Schism").[4][d]

Charlemagne died in 814, having ruled as emperor for thirteen years. He was
laid to rest in his imperial capital city of [Aachen](/wiki/Aachen "Aachen").
He married at least four times and had three legitimate sons, but only his son
[Louis the Pious](/wiki/Louis_the_Pious "Louis the Pious") survived to succeed
him.

## Political
background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Political background")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Francia_at_the_death_of_Pepin_of_Heristal%2C_714.jpg/275px-
Francia_at_the_death_of_Pepin_of_Heristal%2C_714.jpg)](/wiki/File:Francia_at_the_death_of_Pepin_of_Heristal,_714.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Francia_at_the_death_of_Pepin_of_Heristal,_714.jpg "Enlarge")

Francia, early 8th century

By the 6th century, the western [Germanic](/wiki/Germanic_peoples "Germanic
peoples") tribe of the [Franks](/wiki/Franks "Franks") had been
[Christianised](/wiki/Germanic_Christianity "Germanic Christianity"), due in
considerable measure to the Catholic conversion of Clovis I.[5]
[Francia](/wiki/Francia "Francia"), ruled by the
[Merovingians](/wiki/Merovingians "Merovingians"), was the most powerful of
the kingdoms that succeeded the [Western Roman
Empire](/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire "Western Roman Empire").[6] Following the
[Battle of Tertry](/wiki/Battle_of_Tertry "Battle of Tertry") the Merovingians
declined into powerlessness, for which they have been dubbed the _[rois
fainéants](/wiki/Rois_fain%C3%A9ants "Rois fainéants")_ ("do-nothing
kings").[7] Almost all government powers were exercised by their chief
officer, the [mayor of the palace](/wiki/Mayor_of_the_palace "Mayor of the
palace").[e]

In 687, [Pepin of Herstal](/wiki/Pepin_of_Herstal "Pepin of Herstal"), mayor
of the palace of [Austrasia](/wiki/Austrasia "Austrasia"), ended the strife
between various kings and their mayors with his victory at Tertry.[8] He
became the sole governor of the entire Frankish kingdom. Pepin was the
grandson of two important figures of the Austrasian Kingdom: Saint [Arnulf of
Metz](/wiki/Arnulf_of_Metz "Arnulf of Metz") and [Pepin of
Landen](/wiki/Pepin_of_Landen "Pepin of Landen").[9] Pepin of Herstal was
eventually succeeded by his illegitimate son Charles, later known as [Charles
Martel](/wiki/Charles_Martel "Charles Martel") (Charles the Hammer).[10]

After 737, Charles governed the Franks in lieu of a king and declined to call
himself _king_. Charles was succeeded in 741 by his sons
[Carloman](/wiki/Carloman_\(mayor_of_the_palace\) "Carloman \(mayor of the
palace\)") and [Pepin the Short](/wiki/Pepin_the_Short "Pepin the Short"), the
father of Charlemagne. In 743, the brothers placed [Childeric
III](/wiki/Childeric_III "Childeric III") on the throne to curb separatism in
the periphery. He was the last Merovingian king. Carloman resigned office in
746, preferring to enter the church as a monk. Pepin brought the question of
the kingship before [Pope Zachary](/wiki/Pope_Zachary "Pope Zachary"), asking
whether it was logical for a king to have no royal power. The pope handed down
his decision in 749, decreeing that it was better for Pepin to be called king,
as he had the powers of high office as Mayor, so as not to confuse the
hierarchy. He therefore ordered him to become the _true king_.[11]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/16px-

Introduction](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j4PI8dEWTGE),

Academy](/wiki/Khan_Academy "Khan Academy")  
  
In 750, Pepin was elected by an assembly of the Franks, anointed by the
archbishop, and then raised to the office of king. The Pope branded Childeric
III as "the false king" and ordered him into a monastery. The Merovingian
dynasty was thereby replaced by the [Carolingian](/wiki/Carolingian
"Carolingian") dynasty, named after Charles Martel. In 753, [Pope Stephen
II](/wiki/Pope_Stephen_II "Pope Stephen II") fled from Italy to Francia,
appealing to Pepin for assistance for the rights of St. Peter. He was
supported in this appeal by Carloman, Charles' brother. In return, the pope
could provide only legitimacy. He did this by again anointing and confirming
Pepin, this time adding his young sons Carolus (Charlemagne) and Carloman to
the royal patrimony. They thereby became heirs to the realm that already
covered most of western Europe. In 754, Pepin accepted the Pope's invitation
to visit Italy on behalf of St. Peter's rights, dealing successfully with the
[Lombards](/wiki/Lombards "Lombards").[11][12]

Under the Carolingians, the Frankish kingdom spread to encompass an area
including most of Western Europe; the east-west division of the kingdom formed
the basis for modern [France](/wiki/History_of_France "History of France") and
[Germany](/wiki/History_of_Germany "History of Germany"). Orman[13] portrays
the [Treaty of Verdun](/wiki/Treaty_of_Verdun "Treaty of Verdun") (843)
between the warring grandsons of Charlemagne as the foundation event of an
independent France under its first king [Charles the
Bald](/wiki/Charles_the_Bald "Charles the Bald"); an independent Germany under
its first king [Louis the German](/wiki/Louis_the_German "Louis the German");
and an independent intermediate state stretching from the [low
countries](/wiki/Low_countries "Low countries") along the borderlands to south
of Rome under [Lothair I](/wiki/Lothair_I "Lothair I"), who retained the title
of emperor and the capitals [Aachen](/wiki/Aachen "Aachen") and
[Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome") without the jurisdiction. The middle kingdom had
broken up by 890 and partly absorbed into Western kingdom (later France) and
Eastern kingdom (Germany) and the rest developing into smaller "buffer"
nations that exist between France and Germany to this day, namely the
[Benelux](/wiki/Benelux "Benelux") and [Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland
"Switzerland"). The concept and memory of a united Europe remains topical to
the current time and hence Charlemagne is often considered the forefather of
modern Europe.[14]

## Rise to power[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Rise to power")]

### Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Early life")]

#### Date of birth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Date of birth")]

The most likely date of Charlemagne's birth is reconstructed from several
sources. The date of 742—calculated from [Einhard](/wiki/Einhard "Einhard")'s
date of death of January 814 at age 72—predates the marriage of his parents in
744. The year given in the _[Annales Petaviani](/wiki/Annales_Petaviani
"Annales Petaviani")_ , 747, would be more likely, except that it contradicts
Einhard and a few other sources in making Charlemagne seventy years old at his
death. The month and day of 2 April are established by a calendar from [Lorsch
Abbey](/wiki/Lorsch_Abbey "Lorsch Abbey").[15]

In 747, [Easter](/wiki/Easter "Easter") fell on 2 April, a coincidence that
likely would have been remarked upon by chroniclers but was not.[16] If Easter
was being used as the beginning of the calendar year, then 2 April 747 could
have been, by modern reckoning, April 748 (not on Easter). The date favoured
by the preponderance of evidence[17] is 2 April 742, based on Charlemagne's
age at the time of his death.[15] This date supports the concept that
Charlemagne was technically an [illegitimate](/wiki/Illegitimacy
"Illegitimacy") child, although that is not mentioned by Einhard, since he was
born out of wedlock; Pepin and Bertrada were bound by a private contract or
[Friedelehe](/wiki/Friedelehe "Friedelehe")[18] at the time of his birth, but
did not marry until 744.[19]

#### Place of
birth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Place of birth")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Spoorlijn37.png/275px-
Spoorlijn37.png)](/wiki/File:Spoorlijn37.png)

[](/wiki/File:Spoorlijn37.png "Enlarge")

Region of Aachen-Liège (contemporary borders, trade- and travel routes).

Charlemagne's exact birthplace is unknown, although historians have suggested
[Aachen](/wiki/Aachen "Aachen") in modern-day Germany, and
[Liège](/wiki/Li%C3%A8ge "Liège") ([Herstal](/wiki/Herstal "Herstal")) in
present-day Belgium as possible locations.[20] Aachen and Liège are close to
the region from where the Merovingian and Carolingian families originated.
Other cities have been suggested, including [Düren](/wiki/D%C3%BCren "Düren"),
[Gauting](/wiki/Gauting "Gauting"), [Mürlenbach](/wiki/M%C3%BCrlenbach
"Mürlenbach"),[21] [Quierzy](/wiki/Quierzy "Quierzy") and
[Prüm](/wiki/Pr%C3%BCm "Prüm"). No definitive evidence resolves the question.

### Ancestry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Ancestry")]

Charlemagne was the eldest child of [Pepin the Short](/wiki/Pepin_the_Short
"Pepin the Short") (714 – 24 September 768, reigned from 751) and his wife
[Bertrada of Laon](/wiki/Bertrada_of_Laon "Bertrada of Laon") (720 – 12 July
783), daughter of [Caribert of Laon](/wiki/Caribert_of_Laon "Caribert of
Laon") and [Bertrada of Cologne](/wiki/Bertrada_of_Cologne "Bertrada of
Cologne"). Many historians consider Charlemagne (Charles) to have been
illegitimate, although some state that this is arguable,[22] because Pepin did
not marry Bertrada until 749, which was after Charles' birth; this status did
not exclude him from the succession.[23][24][25]

Records name only [Carloman](/wiki/Carloman_I,_King_of_the_Franks "Carloman I,
King of the Franks"), [Gisela](/wiki/Gisela_\(daughter_of_Pepin_the_Short\)
"Gisela \(daughter of Pepin the Short\)"), and three short-lived children
named Pepin, Chrothais and Adelais as his younger siblings.

> It would be folly, I think, to write a word concerning Charles' birth and
> infancy, or even his boyhood, for nothing has ever been written on the
> subject, and there is no one alive now who can give information on it.
> Accordingly, I determined to pass that by as unknown, and to proceed at once
> to treat of his character, his deeds, and such other facts of his life as
> are worth telling and setting forth, and shall first give an account of his
> deeds at home and abroad, then of his character and pursuits, and lastly of
> his administration and death, omitting nothing worth knowing or necessary to
> know.
>
> — [Einhard](/wiki/Einhard "Einhard")[26]

### Ambiguous high
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Ambiguous high office")]

Further information: [Mayor of the Palace](/wiki/Mayor_of_the_Palace "Mayor of
the Palace")

The most powerful officers of the Frankish people, the Mayor of the Palace
(_Maior Domus_) and one or more kings (_rex_ , _reges_), were appointed by the
election of the people. Elections were not periodic, but were held as required
to elect officers _ad quos summa imperii pertinebat_ , "to whom the highest
matters of state pertained". Evidently, interim decisions could be made by the
Pope, which ultimately needed to be ratified using an assembly of the people
that met annually.[27]

Before he was elected king in 750, Pepin was initially a mayor, a high office
he held "as though hereditary" (_velut hereditario fungebatur_). Einhard
explains that "the honour" was usually "given by the people" to the
distinguished, but Pepin the Great and his brother Carloman the Wise received
it as though hereditary, as had their father, [Charles
Martel](/wiki/Charles_Martel "Charles Martel"). There was, however, a certain
ambiguity about quasi-inheritance. The office was treated as joint property:
one Mayorship held by two brothers jointly.[28] Each, however, had his own
geographic jurisdiction. When Carloman decided to resign, becoming ultimately
a Benedictine at [Monte Cassino](/wiki/Monte_Cassino "Monte Cassino"),[29] the
question of the disposition of his quasi-share was settled by the pope. He
converted the Mayorship into a Kingship and awarded the joint property to
Pepin, who gained the right to pass it on by inheritance.[30]

This decision was not accepted by all family members. Carloman had consented
to the temporary tenancy of his own share, which he intended to pass on to his
son, Drogo, when the inheritance should be settled at someone's death. By the
Pope's decision, in which Pepin had a hand, Drogo was to be disqualified as an
heir in favour of his cousin Charles. He took up arms in opposition to the
decision and was joined by [Grifo](/wiki/Grifo "Grifo"), a half-brother of
Pepin and Carloman, who had been given a share by Charles Martel, but was
stripped of it and held under loose arrest by his half-brothers after an
attempt to seize their shares by military action. Grifo perished in combat in
the Battle of [Saint-Jean-de-Maurienne](/wiki/Saint-Jean-de-Maurienne "Saint-
Jean-de-Maurienne") while Drogo was hunted down and taken into custody.[31]

On the death of Pepin, 24 September 768, the kingship passed jointly to his
sons, "with divine assent" (_divino nutu_).[32] According to the _Life_ ,
Pepin died in Paris. The Franks "in general assembly" (_generali conventu_)
gave them both the rank of a king (_reges_) but "partitioned the whole body of
the kingdom equally" (_totum regni corpus ex aequo partirentur_). The
_annals_[33] tell a slightly different version, with the king dying at [St-
Denis](/wiki/Saint-Denis,_Seine-Saint-Denis "Saint-Denis, Seine-Saint-Denis"),
near Paris. The two "lords" (_domni_) were "elevated to kingship" (_elevati
sunt in regnum_), Charles on 9 October in [Noyon](/wiki/Noyon "Noyon"),
Carloman on an unspecified date in [Soissons](/wiki/Soissons "Soissons"). If
born in 742, Charles was 26 years old, but he had been campaigning at his
father's right hand for several years, which may help to account for his
military skill. [Carloman](/wiki/Carloman_I "Carloman I") was 17.

The language in either case suggests that there were not two inheritances,
which would have created distinct kings ruling over distinct kingdoms, but a
single joint inheritance and a joint kingship tenanted by two equal kings,
Charles and his brother Carloman. As before, distinct jurisdictions were
awarded. Charles received Pepin's original share as Mayor: the outer parts of
the kingdom bordering on the sea, namely [Neustria](/wiki/Neustria
"Neustria"), western [Aquitaine](/wiki/Aquitaine "Aquitaine"), and the
northern parts of [Austrasia](/wiki/Austrasia "Austrasia"); while Carloman was
awarded his uncle's former share, the inner parts: southern Austrasia,
[Septimania](/wiki/Septimania "Septimania"), eastern Aquitaine,
[Burgundy](/wiki/Burgundy_\(region\) "Burgundy \(region\)"), Provence, and
[Swabia](/wiki/Swabia "Swabia"), lands bordering [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy").
The question of whether these jurisdictions were joint shares reverting to the
other brother if one brother died or were inherited property passed on to the
descendants of the brother who died was never definitely settled. It came up
repeatedly over the succeeding decades until the grandsons of Charlemagne
created distinct sovereign kingdoms.

### Aquitaine
rebellion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Aquitaine rebellion")]

An inheritance in the countries formerly under Roman law (_[ius](/wiki/Ius
"Ius")_ or _iustitia_) represented not only a transmission of the properties
and privileges but also the encumbrances and obligations attached to the
inheritance. Pepin at his death had been in process of building an empire, a
difficult task. According to Russell:[34]

> In those times, to build a kingdom from an aggregation of small states was
> itself no great difficulty... But to keep the state intact after it had been
> formed was a colossal task... Each of the minor states...had its little
> sovereign...who...gave himself chiefly to...plotting, pillaging and
> fighting.

#### Formation of a new
Aquitania[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Formation of a new Aquitania")]

Main article: [Aquitaine](/wiki/Aquitaine "Aquitaine")

Aquitania under Rome had been in southern [Gaul](/wiki/Gaul "Gaul"), Romanised
and speaking a [Romance language](/wiki/Romance_language "Romance language").
Similarly [Hispania](/wiki/Hispania "Hispania") had been populated by peoples
who spoke various languages, including [Celtic](/wiki/Celtic_language "Celtic
language"), but the area was now populated entirely by Romance language
speakers. Between Aquitania and Hispania were the [Euskaldunak](/wiki/Basques
"Basques"), Latinised to [Vascones](/wiki/Vascones "Vascones"), or
[Basques](/wiki/Basques "Basques"),[35] living in Basque country, Vasconia,
which extended, according to the distributions of place names attributable to
the Basques, most densely in the western [Pyrenees](/wiki/Pyrenees "Pyrenees")
but also as far south as the upper [Ebro River](/wiki/Ebro_River "Ebro River")
in Spain and as far north as the [Garonne River](/wiki/Garonne_River "Garonne
River") in France.[36] The French name, [Gascony](/wiki/Gascony "Gascony"),
derives from [Vasconia](/wiki/Vasconia "Vasconia"). The Romans were never able
to entirely subject Vasconia. The parts they did, in which they placed the
region's first cities, were sources of legions in the Roman army valued for
their fighting abilities. The border with Aquitania was
[Toulouse](/wiki/Toulouse "Toulouse").

At about 660, the [Duchy of Vasconia](/wiki/Duchy_of_Vasconia "Duchy of
Vasconia") united with the [Duchy of Aquitania](/wiki/Duke_of_Aquitaine "Duke
of Aquitaine") to form a single kingdom under [Felix of
Aquitaine](/wiki/Felix_of_Aquitaine "Felix of Aquitaine"), governing from
Toulouse. This was a joint kingship with a 28-year-old Basque king, [Lupus
I](/wiki/Lupus_I_of_Aquitaine "Lupus I of Aquitaine"). _Lupus_ is the Latin
translation of Basque Otsoa, "wolf".[37] The kingdom was sovereign and
independent. Vasconia gave up predation to become a player on the field of
European politics. Whatever arrangements Felix had made with the Merovingians
became null and void. At Felix's death in 670 the joint property of the
kingship reverted entirely to Lupus. As the Basques had no law of joint
inheritance, but practised [primogeniture](/wiki/Primogeniture
"Primogeniture"), Lupus in effect founded a hereditary dynasty of Basque kings
of an expanded Aquitania.[38]

#### Acquisition of Aquitania by the
Carolingians[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Acquisition of Aquitania by the Carolingians")]

Further information: [Umayyad conquest of
Hispania](/wiki/Umayyad_conquest_of_Hispania "Umayyad conquest of Hispania")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Al-
Andalus732.jpg/250px-Al-Andalus732.jpg)](/wiki/File:Al-Andalus732.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Al-Andalus732.jpg "Enlarge")

Moorish Hispania in 732

The Latin chronicles of the end of [Visigothic](/wiki/Visigoths "Visigoths")
[Hispania](/wiki/Hispania "Hispania") omit many details, such as
identification of characters, filling in the gaps and reconciliation of
numerous contradictions.[39] Muslim sources, however, present a more coherent
view, such as in the _Ta 'rikh iftitah al-Andalus_ ("History of the Conquest
of al-Andalus") by [Ibn al-Qūṭiyya](/wiki/Ibn_al-Q%C5%AB%E1%B9%ADiyya "Ibn al-
Qūṭiyya") ("the son of the Gothic woman", referring to the granddaughter of
[Wittiza](/wiki/Wittiza "Wittiza"), the last Visigothic king of a united
Hispania, who married a Moor). Ibn al-Qūṭiyya, who had another, much longer
name, must have been relying to some degree on family oral tradition.

According to Ibn al-Qūṭiyya[40] [Wittiza](/wiki/Wittiza "Wittiza"), |the last
Visigothic king of a united Hispania, died before his three sons, Almund,
Romulo and Ardabast, reached maturity. Their mother was regent at
[Toledo](/wiki/Toledo,_Spain "Toledo, Spain"), but [Roderic](/wiki/Roderic
"Roderic"), army chief of staff, staged a rebellion, capturing
[Córdoba](/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Spain "Córdoba, Spain"). He chose to impose a
joint rule over distinct jurisdictions on the true heirs. Evidence of a
division of some sort can be found in the distribution of coins imprinted with
the name of each king and in the king lists.[41] Wittiza was succeeded by
Roderic, who reigned for seven and a half years, followed by Achila (Aquila),
who reigned three and a half years. If the reigns of both terminated with the
incursion of the [Saracens](/wiki/Saracens "Saracens"), then Roderic appears
to have reigned a few years before the majority of Achila. The latter's
kingdom is securely placed to the northeast, while Roderic seems to have taken
the rest, notably modern [Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal").

The Saracens crossed the mountains to claim Ardo's
[Septimania](/wiki/Septimania "Septimania"), only to encounter the Basque
dynasty of Aquitania, always the allies of the Goths. [Odo the
Great](/wiki/Odo_the_Great "Odo the Great") of [Aquitania](/wiki/Aquitania
"Aquitania") was at first victorious at the [Battle of
Toulouse](/wiki/Battle_of_Toulouse_\(721\) "Battle of Toulouse \(721\)") in
721.[42] Saracen troops gradually massed in Septimania and in 732 an army
under Emir Abd al-Rahman abd Allah al-Ghafiqi advanced into Vasconia, and Odo
was defeated at the [Battle of the River
Garonne](/wiki/Battle_of_the_River_Garonne "Battle of the River Garonne").
They took [Bordeaux](/wiki/Bordeaux "Bordeaux") and were advancing towards
[Tours](/wiki/Tours "Tours") when Odo, powerless to stop them, appealed to his
arch-enemy, [Charles Martel](/wiki/Charles_Martel "Charles Martel"), mayor of
the Franks. In one of the first of the lightning marches for which the
Carolingian kings became famous, Charles and his army appeared in the path of
the Saracens between Tours and [Poitiers](/wiki/Poitiers "Poitiers"), and in
the [Battle of Tours](/wiki/Battle_of_Tours "Battle of Tours") decisively
defeated and killed al-Ghafiqi. The Moors returned twice more, each time
suffering defeat at Charles' hands—at the River Berre near Narbonne in 737[43]
and in the Dauphine in 740.[44] Odo's price for salvation from the Saracens
was incorporation into the Frankish kingdom, a decision that was repugnant to
him and also to his heirs.

#### Loss and recovery of
Aquitania[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Loss and recovery of Aquitania")]

After the death of his father, [Hunald](/wiki/Hunald_of_Aquitaine "Hunald of
Aquitaine") allied himself with free [Lombardy](/wiki/Lombardy "Lombardy").
However, Odo had ambiguously left the kingdom jointly to his two sons,
[Hunald](/wiki/Hunald "Hunald") and Hatto. The latter, loyal to Francia, now
went to war with his brother over full possession. Victorious, Hunald blinded
and imprisoned his brother, only to be so stricken by conscience that he
resigned and entered the church as a monk to do penance. The story is told un
[Annales Mettenses priores](/wiki/Annales_Mettenses_priores "Annales Mettenses
priores").[45] His son [Waifer](/wiki/Waiofar "Waiofar") took an early
inheritance, becoming duke of Aquitania and ratified the alliance with
Lombardy. Waifer decided to honour it, repeating his father's decision, which
he justified by arguing that any agreements with Charles Martel became invalid
on Martel's death. Since [Aquitania](/wiki/Aquitania "Aquitania") was now
Pepin's inheritance because of the earlier assistance given by Charles Martel,
according to some the latter and his son, the young Charles, hunted down
Waifer, who could only conduct a guerrilla war, and executed him.[46]

Among the contingents of the Frankish army were [Bavarians](/wiki/Bavaria
"Bavaria") under [Tassilo III, Duke of
Bavaria](/wiki/Tassilo_III,_Duke_of_Bavaria "Tassilo III, Duke of Bavaria"),
an [Agilofing](/wiki/Agilofing "Agilofing"), the hereditary Bavarian ducal
family. [Grifo](/wiki/Grifo "Grifo") had installed himself as Duke of Bavaria,
but Pepin replaced him with a member of the ducal family yet a child, Tassilo,
whose protector he had become after the death of his father. The loyalty of
the Agilolfings was perpetually in question, but Pepin exacted numerous oaths
of loyalty from Tassilo. However, the latter had married
[Liutperga](/wiki/Liutperga "Liutperga"), a daughter of
[Desiderius](/wiki/Desiderius "Desiderius"), king of [Lombardy](/wiki/Lombardy
"Lombardy"). At a critical point in the campaign, Tassilo left the field with
all his Bavarians. Out of reach of Pepin, he repudiated all loyalty to
Francia.[47] Pepin had no chance to respond as he grew ill and died within a
few weeks after Waifer's execution.

The first event of the brothers' reign was the uprising of the Aquitainians
and [Gascons](/wiki/Gascony "Gascony"), in 769, in that territory split
between the two kings. One year earlier, Pepin had finally defeated
[Waifer](/wiki/Waifer_of_Aquitaine "Waifer of Aquitaine"), [Duke of
Aquitaine](/wiki/Duke_of_Aquitaine "Duke of Aquitaine"), after waging a
destructive, ten-year war against Aquitaine. Now, another Hunald (seemingly
not [Hunald](/wiki/Hunald_of_Aquitaine "Hunald of Aquitaine") the duke) led
the Aquitainians as far north as [Angoulême](/wiki/Angoul%C3%AAme
"Angoulême"). Charles met Carloman, but Carloman refused to participate and
returned to Burgundy. Charles went to war, leading an army to
[Bordeaux](/wiki/Bordeaux "Bordeaux"), where he set up a fort at Fronsac.
Hunald was forced to flee to the court of Duke [Lupus II of
Gascony](/wiki/Lupo_II_of_Gascony "Lupo II of Gascony"). Lupus, fearing
Charles, turned Hunald over in exchange for peace, and was put in a monastery.
Gascon lords also surrendered, and Aquitaine and
[Gascony](/wiki/Duchy_of_Vasconia "Duchy of Vasconia") were finally fully
subdued by the Franks.

### Perforce
union[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Perforce union")]

The brothers maintained lukewarm relations with the assistance of their mother
Bertrada, but in 770 Charles signed a treaty with Duke [Tassilo III of
Bavaria](/wiki/Tassilo_III_of_Bavaria "Tassilo III of Bavaria") and married a
Lombard Princess (commonly known today as
[Desiderata](/wiki/Desiderata,_wife_of_Charlemagne "Desiderata, wife of
Charlemagne")), the daughter of King [Desiderius](/wiki/Desiderius
"Desiderius"), to surround Carloman with his own allies. Though [Pope Stephen
III](/wiki/Pope_Stephen_III "Pope Stephen III") first opposed the marriage
with the Lombard princess, he found little to fear from a Frankish-Lombard
alliance.

Less than a year after his marriage, Charlemagne repudiated Desiderata and
married a 13-year-old Swabian named
[Hildegard](/wiki/Hildegard,_wife_of_Charlemagne "Hildegard, wife of
Charlemagne"). The repudiated Desiderata returned to her father's court at
[Pavia](/wiki/Pavia "Pavia"). Her father's wrath was now aroused, and he would
have gladly allied with Carloman to defeat Charles. Before any open
hostilities could be declared, however, Carloman died on 5 December 771,
apparently of natural causes. Carloman's widow
[Gerberga](/wiki/Gerberge,_wife_of_Carloman "Gerberge, wife of Carloman") fled
to Desiderius' court in Lombardy with her sons for protection.

## Italian
campaigns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Italian campaigns")]

### Conquest of the Lombard
kingdom[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Conquest of the Lombard kingdom")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Charlemagne_and_Pope_Adrian_I.jpg/220px-
Charlemagne_and_Pope_Adrian_I.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_and_Pope_Adrian_I.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_and_Pope_Adrian_I.jpg "Enlarge")

The Frankish king Charlemagne was a devout Catholic and maintained a close
relationship with the papacy throughout his life. In 772, when [Pope Adrian
I](/wiki/Pope_Adrian_I "Pope Adrian I") was threatened by invaders, the king
rushed to Rome to provide assistance. Shown here, the pope asks Charlemagne
for help at a meeting near Rome.

At his succession in 772, [Pope Adrian I](/wiki/Pope_Adrian_I "Pope Adrian I")
demanded the return of certain cities in the former [exarchate of
Ravenna](/wiki/Exarchate_of_Ravenna "Exarchate of Ravenna") in accordance with
a promise at the succession of Desiderius. Instead, Desiderius took over
certain papal cities and invaded the [Pentapolis](/wiki/Pentapolis
"Pentapolis"), heading for Rome. Adrian sent ambassadors to Charlemagne in
autumn requesting he enforce the policies of his father, Pepin. Desiderius
sent his own ambassadors denying the pope's charges. The ambassadors met at
[Thionville](/wiki/Thionville "Thionville"), and Charlemagne upheld the pope's
side. Charlemagne demanded what the pope had requested, but Desiderius swore
never to comply. Charlemagne and his uncle
[Bernard](/wiki/Bernhard,_son_of_Charles_Martel "Bernhard, son of Charles
Martel") crossed the Alps in 773 and chased the Lombards back to [Pavia, which
they then besieged](/wiki/Siege_of_Pavia_\(773%E2%80%9374\) "Siege of Pavia
\(773–74\)").[48] Charlemagne temporarily left the siege to deal with
[Adelchis](/wiki/Adelchis "Adelchis"), son of Desiderius, who was raising an
army at [Verona](/wiki/Verona "Verona"). The young prince was chased to the
[Adriatic](/wiki/Adriatic "Adriatic") littoral and fled to
[Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople") to plead for
assistance from [Constantine V](/wiki/Constantine_V "Constantine V"), who was
waging war with [Bulgaria](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian
Empire").[49][30]

The siege lasted until the spring of 774, when Charlemagne visited the pope in
Rome. There he confirmed his father's grants of land,[50] with some later
chronicles falsely claiming that he also expanded them, granting
[Tuscany](/wiki/Tuscany "Tuscany"), [Emilia](/wiki/Emilia_\(region_of_Italy\)
"Emilia \(region of Italy\)"), Venice and [Corsica](/wiki/Corsica "Corsica").
The pope granted him the title _[patrician](/wiki/Patrician_\(post-
Roman_Europe\) "Patrician \(post-Roman Europe\)")_. He then returned to Pavia,
where the Lombards were on the verge of surrendering. In return for their
lives, the Lombards surrendered and opened the gates in early summer.
Desiderius was sent to the [abbey](/wiki/Abbey "Abbey") of
[Corbie](/wiki/Corbie "Corbie"), and his son Adelchis died in
[Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople"), a patrician. Charles,
unusually, had himself crowned with the [Iron
Crown](/wiki/Iron_Crown_of_Lombardy "Iron Crown of Lombardy") and made the
magnates of Lombardy pay homage to him at Pavia. Only Duke [Arechis II of
Benevento](/wiki/Arechis_II_of_Benevento "Arechis II of Benevento") refused to
submit and proclaimed independence. Charlemagne was then master of Italy as
king of the Lombards. He left Italy with a garrison in Pavia and a few
Frankish counts in place the same year.

Instability continued in Italy. In 776, Dukes [Hrodgaud of
Friuli](/wiki/Hrodgaud_of_Friuli "Hrodgaud of Friuli") and [Hildeprand of
Spoleto](/wiki/Hildeprand_of_Spoleto "Hildeprand of Spoleto") rebelled.
Charlemagne rushed back from [Saxony](/wiki/Saxony "Saxony") and defeated the
duke of Friuli in battle; the duke was slain.[30] The duke of Spoleto signed a
treaty. Their co-conspirator, Arechis, was not subdued, and Adelchis, their
candidate in [Byzantium](/wiki/Byzantium "Byzantium"), never left that city.
Northern Italy was now faithfully his.

### Southern
Italy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Southern Italy")]

In 787, Charlemagne directed his attention towards the [Duchy of
Benevento](/wiki/Duchy_of_Benevento "Duchy of Benevento"),[51] where [Arechis
II](/wiki/Arechis_II_of_Benevento "Arechis II of Benevento") was reigning
independently with the self-given title of [Princeps](/wiki/Princeps
"Princeps"). Charlemagne's siege of [Salerno](/wiki/Salerno "Salerno") forced
Arechis into submission. However, after Arecchis II's death in 787, his son
[Grimoald III](/wiki/Grimoald_III_of_Benevento "Grimoald III of Benevento")
proclaimed the Duchy of Benevento newly independent. Grimoald was attacked
many times by Charles' or his sons' armies, without achieving a definitive
victory.[52] Charlemagne lost interest and never again returned to [Southern
Italy](/wiki/Southern_Italy "Southern Italy") where Grimoald was able to keep
the Duchy free from Frankish [suzerainty](/wiki/Suzerainty "Suzerainty").

## Children[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Children")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Karl_der_Grosse_-
_Pippin_der_Bucklige.jpg/220px-Karl_der_Grosse_-
_Pippin_der_Bucklige.jpg)](/wiki/File:Karl_der_Grosse_-
_Pippin_der_Bucklige.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Karl_der_Grosse_-_Pippin_der_Bucklige.jpg "Enlarge")

Charlemagne (left) and his eldest son, [Pepin the
Hunchback](/wiki/Pepin_the_Hunchback "Pepin the Hunchback"). Tenth-century
copy of a lost original from about 830.

During the first peace of any substantial length (780–782), Charles began to
appoint his sons to positions of authority. In 781, he made his two youngest
sons kings, crowned by the Pope. The elder of these two,
[Carloman](/wiki/Pippin_of_Italy "Pippin of Italy"), was made [king of
Italy](/wiki/King_of_Italy "King of Italy"), taking the Iron Crown that his
father had first worn in 774, and in the same ceremony was renamed
"Pepin".[30][50] The younger of the two, [Louis](/wiki/Louis_the_Pious "Louis
the Pious"), became [king of Aquitaine](/wiki/King_of_Aquitaine "King of
Aquitaine"). Charlemagne ordered Pepin and Louis to be raised in the customs
of their kingdoms, and he gave their regents some control of their sub-
kingdoms, but kept the real power, though he intended his sons to inherit
their realms. He did not tolerate insubordination in his sons: in 792, he
banished his eldest, though possibly illegitimate, son, [Pippin the
Hunchback](/wiki/Pippin_the_Hunchback "Pippin the Hunchback"), to the
monastery of Prüm, because the young man had joined a rebellion against him.

Charles was determined to have his children educated, including his daughters,
as his parents had instilled the importance of learning in him at an early
age.[53] His children were also taught skills in accord with their
aristocratic status, which included training in riding and weaponry for his
sons, and embroidery, spinning and weaving for his daughters.[54]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Charlemagne_et_Louis_le_Pieux.jpg/220px-
Charlemagne_et_Louis_le_Pieux.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_et_Louis_le_Pieux.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_et_Louis_le_Pieux.jpg "Enlarge")

Charlemagne instructing his son [Louis the Pious](/wiki/Louis_the_Pious "Louis
the Pious")

The sons fought many wars on behalf of their father.
[Charles](/wiki/Charles_the_Younger "Charles the Younger") was mostly
preoccupied with the Bretons, whose border he shared and who insurrected on at
least two occasions and were easily put down. He also fought the Saxons on
multiple occasions. In 805 and 806, he was sent into the Böhmerwald (modern
[Bohemia](/wiki/Bohemia "Bohemia")) to deal with the Slavs living there
(Bohemian tribes, ancestors of the modern [Czechs](/wiki/Czech_people "Czech
people")). He subjected them to Frankish authority and devastated the valley
of the Elbe, forcing tribute from them. Pippin had to hold the
[Avar](/wiki/Avars_\(Carpathians\) "Avars \(Carpathians\)") and Beneventan
borders and fought the [Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") to his north. He was
uniquely poised to fight the [Byzantine Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire
"Byzantine Empire") when that conflict arose after Charlemagne's imperial
coronation and a [Venetian](/wiki/Venetia_\(region\) "Venetia \(region\)")
rebellion. Finally, Louis was in charge of the [Spanish
March](/wiki/Spanish_March "Spanish March") and fought the duke of Benevento
in southern Italy on at least one occasion. He took
[Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona") in a great siege in 797.

Charlemagne's attitude towards his daughters has been the subject of much
discussion. He kept them at home with him and refused to allow them to
contract [sacramental marriages](/wiki/Marriage#Marriage_and_religion
"Marriage") (though he originally condoned an engagement between his eldest
daughter Rotrude and [Constantine VI](/wiki/Constantine_VI "Constantine VI")
of Byzantium, this engagement was annulled when Rotrude was 11).[55]
Charlemagne's opposition to his daughters' marriages may possibly have
intended to prevent the creation of [cadet branches](/wiki/Cadet_branch "Cadet
branch") of the family to challenge the main line, as had been the case with
[Tassilo of Bavaria](/wiki/Tassilo_III_of_Bavaria "Tassilo III of Bavaria").
However, he tolerated their extramarital relationships, even rewarding their
common-law husbands and treasuring the illegitimate grandchildren they
produced for him. He also, apparently, refused to believe stories of their
wild behaviour. After his death the surviving daughters were banished from the
court by their brother, the pious Louis, to take up residence in the convents
they had been bequeathed by their father. At least one of them, Bertha, had a
recognised relationship, if not a marriage, with [Angilbert](/wiki/Angilbert
"Angilbert"), a member of Charlemagne's court circle.[56][57]

south[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Carolingian expansion to the south")]
