### Vasconia and the
Pyrenees[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Vasconia and the Pyrenees")]

The destructive war led by Pepin in Aquitaine, although brought to a
satisfactory conclusion for the Franks, that proved the Frankish power
structure south of the [Loire](/wiki/Loire "Loire") was feeble and unreliable.
After the defeat and death of [Waiofar](/wiki/Waiofar "Waiofar") in 768, while
Aquitaine submitted again to the Carolingian dynasty, a new rebellion broke
out in 769 led by Hunald II, a possible son of Waifer. He took refuge with the
ally duke [Lupus II of Gascony](/wiki/Lupus_II_of_Gascony "Lupus II of
Gascony"), but probably out of fear of Charlemagne's reprisal, handed him over
to the new King of the Franks to whom he pledged loyalty, which seemed to
confirm the peace in [the Basque area](/wiki/Duchy_of_Vasconia "Duchy of
Vasconia") south of the [Garonne](/wiki/Garonne "Garonne").

Wary of new Basque uprisings, Charlemagne seems to have tried to contain duke
Lupus's power by appointing [Seguin](/wiki/Seguin_I_of_Gascony "Seguin I of
Gascony") as count of Bordeaux (778) and other counts of Frankish background
in bordering areas
([Toulouse](/wiki/History_of_Toulouse#768.E2.80.93877:_Carolingian_Franks_and_the_Kingdom_of_Aquitaine
"History of Toulouse"), [County of Fézensac](/wiki/County_of_F%C3%A9zensac
"County of Fézensac")). The
[Basque](/wiki/History_of_the_Basque_people#Early_Middle_Ages "History of the
Basque people") duke in turn seems to have contributed decisively or schemed
the [Battle of Roncevaux Pass](/wiki/Battle_of_Roncevaux_Pass "Battle of
Roncevaux Pass") (referred to as "Basque treachery"). The defeat of
Charlemagne's army in Roncevaux (778) confirmed his determination to rule
directly by establishing the Kingdom of Aquitaine (ruled by [Louis the
Pious](/wiki/Louis_the_Pious "Louis the Pious")) based on a power base of
Frankish officials, distributing lands among colonisers and allocating lands
to the Church, which he took as ally. A Christianisation programme was put in
place across the high [Pyrenees](/wiki/Pyrenees "Pyrenees") (778).

The new political arrangement for Vasconia did not sit well with local lords.
As of 788 [Adalric](/wiki/Adalric_of_Gascony "Adalric of Gascony") was
fighting and capturing [Chorson](/wiki/Torson_of_Toulouse "Torson of
Toulouse"), Carolingian count of Toulouse. He was eventually released, but
Charlemagne, enraged at the compromise, decided to depose him and appointed
his trustee [William of Gellone](/wiki/William_of_Gellone "William of
Gellone"). William in turn fought the Basques and defeated them after
banishing Adalric (790).

From 781 ([Pallars](/wiki/County_of_Pallars "County of Pallars"),
[Ribagorça](/wiki/County_of_Ribagorza "County of Ribagorza")) to 806
([Pamplona](/wiki/Pamplona#Early_Middle_Ages "Pamplona") under Frankish
influence), taking the County of Toulouse for a power base, Charlemagne
asserted Frankish authority over the Pyrenees by subduing the south-western
marches of Toulouse (790) and establishing vassal counties on the southern
Pyrenees that were to make up the [Marca Hispanica](/wiki/Marca_Hispanica
"Marca Hispanica"). As of 794, a Frankish vassal, the Basque lord Belasko
(_al-Galashki_ , 'the Gaul') ruled [Álava](/wiki/%C3%81lava "Álava"), but
Pamplona remained under Cordovan and local control up to 806. Belasko and the
counties in the Marca Hispánica provided the necessary base to attack the
[Andalusians](/wiki/Al-Andalus "Al-Andalus") (an expedition led by [William
Count of Toulouse](/wiki/William_of_Gellone "William of Gellone") and Louis
the Pious to capture Barcelona in 801). Events in the Duchy of Vasconia
(rebellion in Pamplona, [count overthrown in
Aragon](/wiki/Aznar_Gal%C3%ADndez_I "Aznar Galíndez I"), duke Seguin of
Bordeaux deposed, uprising of the Basque lords, etc.) were to prove it
ephemeral upon Charlemagne's death.

### Roncesvalles
campaign[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Roncesvalles campaign")]

According to the Muslim historian [Ibn al-Athir](/wiki/Ibn_al-Athir "Ibn al-
Athir"), the Diet of Paderborn had received the representatives of the Muslim
rulers of [Zaragoza](/wiki/Zaragoza "Zaragoza"), [Girona](/wiki/Girona
"Girona"), [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona") and [Huesca](/wiki/Huesca
"Huesca"). Their masters had been cornered in the [Iberian
peninsula](/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula") by [Abd ar-Rahman
I](/wiki/Abd_ar-Rahman_I "Abd ar-Rahman I"), the [Umayyad](/wiki/Umayyad
"Umayyad") [emir of Cordova](/wiki/Emir_of_C%C3%B3rdoba "Emir of Córdoba").
These "Saracen" ([Moorish](/wiki/Moorish "Moorish") and [Muladi](/wiki/Muladi
"Muladi")) rulers offered their homage to the king of the Franks in return for
military support. Seeing an opportunity to extend
[Christendom](/wiki/Christendom "Christendom") and his own power and believing
the Saxons to be a fully conquered nation, Charlemagne agreed to go to Spain.

In 778, he led the Neustrian army across the Western [Pyrenees](/wiki/Pyrenees
"Pyrenees"), while the Austrasians, Lombards, and Burgundians passed over the
Eastern Pyrenees. The armies met at Saragossa and Charlemagne received the
homage of the Muslim rulers, Sulayman al-Arabi and Kasmin ibn Yusuf, but the
city did not fall for him. Indeed, Charlemagne faced the toughest battle of
his career. The Muslims forced him to retreat. He decided to go home, since he
could not trust the [Basques](/wiki/Basques "Basques"), whom he had subdued by
conquering [Pamplona](/wiki/Pamplona "Pamplona"). He turned to leave Iberia,
but as he was passing through the Pass of [Roncesvalles](/wiki/Roncesvalles
"Roncesvalles") one of the most famous events of his reign occurred. The
Basques attacked and destroyed his rearguard and baggage train. The [Battle of
Roncevaux Pass](/wiki/Battle_of_Roncevaux_Pass "Battle of Roncevaux Pass"),
though less a battle than a skirmish, left many famous dead, including the
[seneschal](/wiki/Seneschal "Seneschal") Eggihard, the count of the palace
Anselm, and the [warden](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/warden "wikt:warden")
of the [Breton March](/wiki/Breton_March "Breton March"),
[Roland](/wiki/Roland "Roland"), inspiring the subsequent creation of the
[Song of Roland](/wiki/Song_of_Roland "Song of Roland") (_La Chanson de
Roland_).

### Contact with the
Saracens[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Contact with the Saracens")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Harun-
Charlemagne.jpg/300px-Harun-Charlemagne.jpg)](/wiki/File:Harun-
Charlemagne.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Harun-Charlemagne.jpg "Enlarge")

[Harun al-Rashid](/wiki/Harun_al-Rashid "Harun al-Rashid") receiving a
delegation of Charlemagne in [Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad"), by [Julius
Köckert](/w/index.php?title=Julius_K%C3%B6ckert&action=edit&redlink=1 "Julius
Köckert \(page does not exist\)") (1864).

The conquest of Italy brought Charlemagne in contact with the
[Saracens](/wiki/Saracen "Saracen") who, at the time, controlled the
[Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea"). Pippin was much
occupied with Saracens in Italy. Charlemagne conquered [Corsica](/wiki/Corsica
"Corsica") and [Sardinia](/wiki/Sardinia "Sardinia") at an unknown date and in
799 the [Balearic Islands](/wiki/Balearic_Islands "Balearic Islands"). The
islands were often attacked by Saracen pirates, but the counts of
[Genoa](/wiki/Genoa "Genoa") and Tuscany
([Boniface](/wiki/Boniface_I_of_Tuscany "Boniface I of Tuscany")) controlled
them with large fleets until the end of Charlemagne's reign. Charlemagne even
had contact with the [caliphal](/wiki/Caliph "Caliph") court in
[Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad"). In 797 (or possibly 801), the caliph of
Baghdad, [Harun al-Rashid](/wiki/Harun_al-Rashid "Harun al-Rashid"), presented
Charlemagne with an [Asian elephant](/wiki/Asian_elephant "Asian elephant")
named [Abul-Abbas](/wiki/Abul-Abbas "Abul-Abbas") and a [clock](/wiki/Clock
"Clock").[58]

### Wars with the
Moors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Wars with the Moors")]

In [Hispania](/wiki/Hispania "Hispania"), the struggle against the Moors
continued unabated throughout the latter half of his reign. Louis was in
charge of the Spanish border. In 785, his men captured Girona permanently and
extended Frankish control into the [Catalan](/wiki/Catalonia "Catalonia")
littoral for the duration of Charlemagne's reign (the area remained nominally
Frankish until the [Treaty of Corbeil](/wiki/Treaty_of_Corbeil_\(1258\)
"Treaty of Corbeil \(1258\)") in 1258). The Muslim chiefs in the northeast of
[Islamic Spain](/wiki/Al-Andalus "Al-Andalus") were constantly rebelling
against Cordovan authority, and they often turned to the Franks for help. The
Frankish border was slowly extended until 795, when Girona,
[Cardona](/wiki/Cardona,_Spain "Cardona, Spain"), [Ausona](/wiki/Ausona
"Ausona") and [Urgell](/wiki/County_of_Urgell "County of Urgell") were united
into the new [Spanish March](/wiki/Spanish_March "Spanish March"), within the
old duchy of [Septimania](/wiki/Septimania "Septimania").

In 797, [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), the greatest city of the
region, fell to the Franks when Zeid, its governor, rebelled against Cordova
and, failing, handed it to them. The [Umayyad](/wiki/Umayyad "Umayyad")
authority recaptured it in 799. However, Louis of Aquitaine marched the entire
army of his kingdom over the [Pyrenees](/wiki/Pyrenees "Pyrenees") and
besieged it for two years, wintering there from 800 to 801, when it
capitulated. The Franks continued to press forward against the
[emir](/wiki/Emir "Emir"). They took [Tarragona](/wiki/Tarragona "Tarragona")
in 809 and [Tortosa](/wiki/Tortosa "Tortosa") in 811. The last conquest
brought them to the mouth of the [Ebro](/wiki/Ebro "Ebro") and gave them
raiding access to [Valencia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Valencia "Kingdom of Valencia"),
prompting the Emir [al-Hakam I](/wiki/Al-Hakam_I "Al-Hakam I") to recognise
their conquests in 813.

## Eastern
campaigns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Eastern campaigns")]

### Saxon Wars[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Saxon Wars")]

Further information: [Saxon Wars](/wiki/Saxon_Wars "Saxon Wars")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Frankish_Empire_481_to_814-en.svg/300px-
Frankish_Empire_481_to_814-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Frankish_Empire_481_to_814-en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Frankish_Empire_481_to_814-en.svg "Enlarge")

A map showing Charlemagne's additions (in light green) to the Frankish Kingdom

Charlemagne was engaged in almost constant warfare throughout his reign,[59]
often at the head of his elite _[scara](/wiki/Scara "Scara")_ bodyguard
squadrons, carrying his legendary sword [Joyeuse](/wiki/Joyeuse "Joyeuse"). In
the [Saxon Wars](/wiki/Saxon_Wars "Saxon Wars"), spanning thirty years and
eighteen battles, he conquered [Saxonia](/wiki/Old_Saxony "Old Saxony") and
proceeded to convert it to Christianity.

The [Germanic](/wiki/Germanic_peoples "Germanic peoples")
[Saxons](/wiki/Saxons "Saxons") were divided into four subgroups in four
regions. Nearest to [Austrasia](/wiki/Austrasia "Austrasia") was
[Westphalia](/wiki/Westphalia "Westphalia") and furthest away was
[Eastphalia](/wiki/Eastphalia "Eastphalia"). Between them was
[Engria](/wiki/Engria "Engria") and north of these three, at the base of the
[Jutland](/wiki/Jutland "Jutland") peninsula, was
[Nordalbingia](/wiki/Nordalbingia "Nordalbingia").

In his first campaign, in 773, Charlemagne forced the Engrians to submit and
cut down an [Irminsul](/wiki/Irminsul "Irminsul") pillar near
[Paderborn](/wiki/Paderborn "Paderborn").[60] The campaign was cut short by
his first expedition to Italy. He returned in 775, marching through Westphalia
and conquering the Saxon fort at [Sigiburg](/wiki/Sigiburg "Sigiburg"). He
then crossed Engria, where he defeated the Saxons again. Finally, in
Eastphalia, he defeated a Saxon force, and its leader
[Hessi](/w/index.php?title=Hessi&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hessi \(page does not
exist\)") converted to Christianity. Charlemagne returned through Westphalia,
leaving encampments at Sigiburg and [Eresburg](/wiki/Eresburg "Eresburg"),
which had been important Saxon bastions. He then controlled Saxony with the
exception of Nordalbingia, but Saxon resistance had not ended.

Following his subjugation of the dukes of Friuli and Spoleto, Charlemagne
returned rapidly to Saxony in 776, where a rebellion had destroyed his
fortress at Eresburg. The Saxons were once again defeated, but their main
leader, [Widukind](/wiki/Widukind "Widukind"), escaped to Denmark, his wife's
home. Charlemagne built a new camp at [Karlstadt](/wiki/Karlstadt_am_Main
"Karlstadt am Main"). In 777, he called a national diet at Paderborn to
integrate Saxony fully into the Frankish kingdom. Many Saxons were baptised as
Christians.

In the summer of 779, he again invaded Saxony and reconquered Eastphalia,
Engria and Westphalia. At a diet near [Lippe](/wiki/Lippe "Lippe"), he divided
the land into missionary districts and himself assisted in several mass
baptisms (780). He then returned to Italy and, for the first time, the Saxons
did not immediately revolt. Saxony was peaceful from 780 to 782.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Ary_Scheffer%2C_Charlemagne_re%C3%A7oit_la_soumission_de_Widukind_%C3%A0_Paderborn%2C_%281840%29.jpg/240px-
Ary_Scheffer%2C_Charlemagne_re%C3%A7oit_la_soumission_de_Widukind_%C3%A0_Paderborn%2C_%281840%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ary_Scheffer,_Charlemagne_re%C3%A7oit_la_soumission_de_Widukind_%C3%A0_Paderborn,_\(1840\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ary_Scheffer,_Charlemagne_re%C3%A7oit_la_soumission_de_Widukind_%C3%A0_Paderborn,_\(1840\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Charlemagne (742–814) receiving the submission of [Widukind](/wiki/Widukind
"Widukind") at [Paderborn](/wiki/Paderborn "Paderborn") in 785, by [Ary
Scheffer](/wiki/Ary_Scheffer "Ary Scheffer") (1795–1858), [Palace of
Versailles](/wiki/Palace_of_Versailles "Palace of Versailles")

He returned to Saxony in 782 and instituted a code of law and appointed
counts, both Saxon and Frank. The laws were
[draconian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/draconian "wikt:draconian") on
religious issues; for example, the _[Capitulatio de partibus
Saxoniae](/wiki/Capitulatio_de_partibus_Saxoniae "Capitulatio de partibus
Saxoniae")_ prescribed death to Saxon pagans who refused to convert to
Christianity. This led to renewed conflict. That year, in autumn, Widukind
returned and led a new revolt. In response, at [Verden](/wiki/Verden,_Germany
"Verden, Germany") in Lower Saxony, Charlemagne is recorded as having ordered
the execution of 4,500 Saxon prisoners, known as the [Massacre of
Verden](/wiki/Massacre_of_Verden "Massacre of Verden") ("Verdener
Blutgericht"). The killings triggered three years of renewed bloody warfare
(783–785). During this war the [Frisians](/wiki/Frisians "Frisians") were
finally subdued and a large part of their fleet was burned. The war ended with
[Widukind](/wiki/Widukind "Widukind") accepting baptism.

Thereafter, the Saxons maintained the peace for seven years, but in 792
Westphalia again rebelled. The Eastphalians and Nordalbingians joined them in
793, but the insurrection was unpopular and was put down by 794. An Engrian
rebellion followed in 796, but the presence of Charlemagne, Christian Saxons
and [Slavs](/wiki/Slavic_peoples "Slavic peoples") quickly crushed it. The
last insurrection occurred in 804, more than thirty years after Charlemagne's
first campaign against them, but also failed. According to Einhard:

> The war that had lasted so many years was at length ended by their acceding
> to the terms offered by the King; which were renunciation of their national
> religious customs and the worship of devils, acceptance of the sacraments of
> the Christian faith and religion, and union with the Franks to form one
> people.

### Submission of
Bavaria[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Submission of Bavaria")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Charlemagne_Agostino_Cornacchini_Vatican_2.jpg/220px-
Charlemagne_Agostino_Cornacchini_Vatican_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_Agostino_Cornacchini_Vatican_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_Agostino_Cornacchini_Vatican_2.jpg "Enlarge")

Statue of Charlemagne by [Agostino Cornacchini](/wiki/Agostino_Cornacchini
"Agostino Cornacchini") (1725), [St. Peter's
Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica"), Vatican, Italy

By 774, Charlemagne had invaded the [Kingdom of
Lombardy](/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Lombards "Kingdom of the Lombards"), and he
later annexed the Lombardian territories and assumed its crown, placing the
[Papal States](/wiki/Papal_States "Papal States") under Frankish
protection.[61] The [Duchy of Spoleto](/wiki/Duchy_of_Spoleto "Duchy of
Spoleto") south of Rome was acquired in 774, while in the central western
parts of Europe, the [Duchy of Bavaria](/wiki/Duchy_of_Bavaria "Duchy of
Bavaria") was absorbed and the Bavarian policy continued of establishing
tributary [marches](/wiki/Marches "Marches"), (borders protected in return for
tribute or taxes) among the [Slavic](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") Serbs and Czechs.
The remaining power confronting the Franks in the east were the
[Avars](/wiki/Avar_people_\(Caucasus\) "Avar people \(Caucasus\)"), however
Charlemagne acquired other Slavic areas, including [Bohemia](/wiki/Bohemia
"Bohemia"), [Moravia](/wiki/Moravia "Moravia"), [Austria](/wiki/Austria
"Austria") and [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia").[61]

In 789, Charlemagne turned to [Bavaria](/wiki/Bavaria "Bavaria"). He claimed
that [Tassilo III, Duke of Bavaria](/wiki/Tassilo_III,_Duke_of_Bavaria
"Tassilo III, Duke of Bavaria") was an unfit ruler, due to his oath-breaking.
The charges were exaggerated, but Tassilo was deposed anyway and put in the
monastery of [Jumièges](/wiki/Jumi%C3%A8ges "Jumièges").[62] In 794, Tassilo
was made to renounce any claim to Bavaria for himself and his family (the
[Agilolfings](/wiki/Agilolfings "Agilolfings")) at the [synod](/wiki/Synod
"Synod") of [Frankfurt](/wiki/Frankfurt "Frankfurt"); he formally handed over
to the king all of the rights he had held. [63]Bavaria was subdivided into
Frankish counties, as had been done with Saxony.

### Avar
campaigns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Avar campaigns")]

In 788, the [Avars](/wiki/Avars_\(Carpathians\) "Avars \(Carpathians\)"), a
pagan Asian horde that had settled down in what is today
[Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary") (Einhard called them [Huns](/wiki/Huns
"Huns")), invaded Friuli and Bavaria. Charlemagne was preoccupied with other
matters until 790, when he marched down the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube")
and ravaged Avar territory to the [Győr](/wiki/Gy%C5%91r "Győr"). A Lombard
army under Pippin then marched into the [Drava](/wiki/Drava "Drava") valley
and ravaged [Pannonia](/wiki/Pannonia "Pannonia"). The campaigns ended when
the Saxons revolted again in 792.

For the next two years, Charlemagne was occupied, along with the Slavs,
against the Saxons. Pippin and Duke [Eric of Friuli](/wiki/Eric_of_Friuli
"Eric of Friuli") continued, however, to assault the Avars' ring-shaped
strongholds. The great Ring of the Avars, their capital fortress, was taken
twice. The booty was sent to Charlemagne at his capital, [Aachen](/wiki/Aachen
"Aachen"), and redistributed to his followers and to foreign rulers, including
King [Offa of Mercia](/wiki/Offa_of_Mercia "Offa of Mercia"). Soon the Avar
[tuduns](/wiki/Tudun "Tudun") had lost the will to fight and travelled to
Aachen to become vassals to Charlemagne and to become Christians. Charlemagne
accepted their surrender and sent one native chief, baptised Abraham, back to
Avaria with the ancient title of [khagan](/wiki/Khagan "Khagan"). Abraham kept
his people in line, but in 800, the [Bulgarians](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire
"First Bulgarian Empire") under [Khan Krum](/wiki/Krum "Krum") attacked the
remains of the Avar state.

In 803, Charlemagne sent a Bavarian army into [Pannonia](/wiki/Pannonia
"Pannonia"), defeating and bringing an end to the [Avar
confederation](/wiki/Avar_Khaganate "Avar Khaganate").[64]

In November of the same year, Charlemagne went to Regensburg where the Avar
leaders acknowledged him as their ruler.[64] In 805, the Avar khagan, who had
already been baptised, went to Aachen to ask permission to settle with his
people south-eastward from [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna").[64] The
[Transdanubian](/wiki/Transdanubia "Transdanubia") territories became integral
parts of the Frankish realm, which was abolished by the
[Magyars](/wiki/Magyars "Magyars") in 899-900.

### Northeast Slav
expeditions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Northeast Slav expeditions")]

In 789, in recognition of his new pagan neighbours, the
[Slavs](/wiki/Slavic_peoples "Slavic peoples"), Charlemagne marched an
Austrasian-Saxon army across the [Elbe](/wiki/Elbe "Elbe") into
[Obotrite](/wiki/Obotrite "Obotrite") territory. The Slavs ultimately
submitted, led by their leader Witzin. Charlemagne then accepted the surrender
of the [Wiltzes](/wiki/Wiltzes "Wiltzes") under Dragovit and demanded many
hostages. He also demanded the permission to send missionaries into this pagan
region unmolested. The army marched to the [Baltic](/wiki/Baltic_region
"Baltic region") before turning around and marching to the Rhine, winning much
booty with no harassment. The tributary Slavs became loyal allies. In 795,
when the Saxons broke the peace, the Abotrites and Wiltzes rebelled with their
new ruler against the Saxons. Witzin died in battle and Charlemagne avenged
him by harrying the Eastphalians on the Elbe. Thrasuco, his successor, led his
men to conquest over the Nordalbingians and handed their leaders over to
Charlemagne, who honoured him. The Abotrites remained loyal until Charles'
death and fought later against the Danes.

### Southeast Slav
expeditions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Southeast Slav expeditions")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Europe_around_800.gif/250px-
Europe_around_800.gif)](/wiki/File:Europe_around_800.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Europe_around_800.gif "Enlarge")

Europe around 800

When Charlemagne incorporated much of Central Europe, he brought the Frankish
state face to face with the Avars and Slavs in the southeast.[65] The most
southeast Frankish neighbours were [Croats](/wiki/Croats "Croats"), who
settled in [Pannonian Croatia](/wiki/Pannonian_Croatia "Pannonian Croatia")
and [Dalmatian Croatia](/wiki/Dalmatian_Croatia "Dalmatian Croatia"). While
fighting the Avars, the Franks had called for their support.[66] During the
790s, he won a major victory over them in 796.[67] Pannonian Croat duke
[Vojnomir of Pannonian Croatia](/wiki/Vojnomir_of_Pannonian_Croatia "Vojnomir
of Pannonian Croatia") aided Charlemagne, and the Franks made themselves
overlords over the Croats of northern Dalmatia, [Slavonia](/wiki/Slavonia
"Slavonia") and Pannonia.[67]

The Frankish commander [Eric of Friuli](/wiki/Eric_of_Friuli "Eric of Friuli")
wanted to extend his dominion by conquering the Littoral Croat Duchy. During
that time, Dalmatian Croatia was ruled by duke [Višeslav of
Croatia](/wiki/Vi%C5%A1eslav_of_Croatia "Višeslav of Croatia"). In the [Battle
of Trsat](/wiki/Siege_of_Trsat "Siege of Trsat"), the forces of Eric fled
their positions and were routed by the forces of Višeslav.[68] Eric was among
those killed which was a great blow for the Carolingian Empire.[65][68][69]

Charlemagne also directed his attention to the [Slavs](/wiki/South_Slavs
"South Slavs") to the west of the Avar khaganate: the
[Carantanians](/wiki/Carantania "Carantania") and [Carniolans](/wiki/Carniola
"Carniola"). These people were subdued by the Lombards and Bavarii and made
tributaries, but were never fully incorporated into the Frankish state.

## Imperium[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=28 "Edit
section: Imperium")]

### Coronation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Coronation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Friedrich_Kaulbach_-
_Kr%C3%B6nung_Karls_des_Gro%C3%9Fen.jpg/300px-Friedrich_Kaulbach_-
_Kr%C3%B6nung_Karls_des_Gro%C3%9Fen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Friedrich_Kaulbach_-
_Kr%C3%B6nung_Karls_des_Gro%C3%9Fen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Friedrich_Kaulbach_-_Kr%C3%B6nung_Karls_des_Gro%C3%9Fen.jpg
"Enlarge")

Imperial Coronation of Charlemagne, by [Friedrich
Kaulbach](/wiki/Friedrich_Kaulbach "Friedrich Kaulbach"), 1861

In 799, [Pope Leo III](/wiki/Pope_Leo_III "Pope Leo III") had been mistreated
by the Romans, who tried to put out his eyes and tear out his tongue.[70] Leo
escaped and fled to Charlemagne at [Paderborn](/wiki/Paderborn
"Paderborn").[71] Charlemagne, advised by scholar [Alcuin](/wiki/Alcuin
"Alcuin"), travelled to Rome, in November 800 and held a council on 1
December.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] On 23 December, Leo swore an oath of innocence.
At [Mass](/wiki/Mass_\(liturgy\) "Mass \(liturgy\)"), on Christmas Day (25
December), when Charlemagne knelt at the altar to pray, the Pope
[crowned](/wiki/Coronation_of_the_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Coronation of the Holy
Roman Emperor") him _Imperator Romanorum_ ("Emperor of the Romans") in [Saint
Peter's Basilica](/wiki/Old_Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica "Old Saint Peter's
Basilica"). In so doing, the Pope effectively nullified the legitimacy of
[Empress Irene](/wiki/Empress_Irene "Empress Irene") of
[Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople"):

> When [Odoacer](/wiki/Odoacer "Odoacer") compelled the abdication of [Romulus
> Augustulus](/wiki/Romulus_Augustulus "Romulus Augustulus"), he did not
> abolish the Western Empire as a separate power, but cause it to be reunited
> with or sink into the Eastern, so that from that time there was a single
> undivided Roman Empire ... [Pope Leo III and Charlemagne], like their
> predecessors, held the Roman Empire to be one and indivisible, and proposed
> by the coronation of [Charlemagne] not to proclaim a severance of the East
> and West ... they were not revolting against a reigning sovereign, but
> legitimately filling up the place of the deposed [Constantine
> VI](/wiki/Constantine_VI "Constantine VI") ... [Charlemagne] was held to be
> the legitimate successor, not of Romulus Augustulus, but of Constantine VI
> ...[72]

Charlemagne's coronation as Emperor, though intended to represent the
continuation of the unbroken line of Emperors from [Augustus](/wiki/Augustus
"Augustus") to Constantine VI, had the effect of setting up two separate (and
often opposing) Empires and two separate claims to imperial authority. For
centuries to come, the Emperors of both West and East would make competing
claims of sovereignty over the whole.

Einhard says that Charlemagne was ignorant of the Pope's intent and did not
want any such coronation:

> [H]e at first had such an aversion that he declared that he would not have
> set foot in the Church the day that they [the imperial titles] were
> conferred, although it was a great feast-day, if he could have foreseen the
> design of the Pope.[73]

A number of modern scholars, however,[74] suggest that Charlemagne was indeed
aware of the coronation; certainly he cannot have missed the bejewelled crown
waiting on the altar when he came to pray; something even contemporary sources
support.[75]

#### Debate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=30 "Edit
section: Debate")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Aachener_Dom_BW_2016-07-09_13-49-15.jpg/200px-
Aachener_Dom_BW_2016-07-09_13-49-15.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aachener_Dom_BW_2016-07-09_13-49-15.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aachener_Dom_BW_2016-07-09_13-49-15.jpg "Enlarge")

The throne of Charlemagne and the subsequent German Kings in [Aachen
Cathedral](/wiki/Aachen_Cathedral "Aachen Cathedral").

Historians have debated for centuries whether Charlemagne was aware before the
coronation of the Pope's intention to crown him Emperor (Charlemagne declared
that he would not have entered Saint Peter's had he known, according to
chapter twenty-eight of Einhard's _Vita Karoli Magni_), but that debate
obscured the more significant question of _why_ the Pope granted the title and
why Charlemagne accepted it.[76]

[Collins](/wiki/Roger_Collins "Roger Collins") points out "[t]hat the
motivation behind the acceptance of the imperial title was a romantic and
antiquarian interest in reviving the Roman empire is highly unlikely."[77] For
one thing, such romance would not have appealed either to Franks or Roman
Catholics at the turn of the ninth century, both of whom viewed the
[Classical](/wiki/Classical_antiquity "Classical antiquity") heritage of the
Roman Empire with distrust. The Franks took pride in having "fought against
and thrown from their shoulders the heavy yoke of the Romans" and "from the
knowledge gained in baptism, clothed in gold and precious stones the bodies of
the holy martyrs whom the Romans had killed by fire, by the sword and by wild
animals", as [Pippin III](/wiki/Pepin_the_Short "Pepin the Short") described
it in a law of 763 or 764.[78]

Furthermore, the new title—carrying with it the risk that the new emperor
would "make drastic changes to the traditional styles and procedures of
government" or "concentrate his attentions on Italy or on Mediterranean
concerns more generally"—risked alienating the Frankish leadership.[79]

For both the Pope and Charlemagne, the Roman Empire remained a significant
power in European politics at this time. The Hellenic [Eastern
Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire"), based in
[Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople"), continued to hold a
substantial portion of Italy, with borders not far south of Rome. Charles'
sitting in judgment of the Pope could be seen as usurping the prerogatives of
the Emperor in Constantinople:

> By whom, however, could he [the Pope] be tried? Who, in other words, was
> qualified to pass judgement on the Vicar of Christ? In normal circumstances
> the only conceivable answer to that question would have been the Emperor at
> Constantinople; but the imperial throne was at this moment occupied by
> [Irene](/wiki/Irene_of_Athens "Irene of Athens"). That the Empress was
> notorious for having blinded and murdered her own son was, in the minds of
> both Leo and Charles, almost immaterial: it was enough that she was a woman.
> The female sex was known to be incapable of governing, and by the old Salic
> tradition was debarred from doing so. As far as Western Europe was
> concerned, the Throne of the Emperors was vacant: Irene's claim to it was
> merely an additional proof, if any were needed, of the degradation into
> which the so-called Roman Empire had fallen.
>
> — [John Julius Norwich](/wiki/John_Julius_Norwich "John Julius Norwich")[80]

For the Pope, then, there was "no living Emperor at the that time"[81] though
[Henri Pirenne](/wiki/Henri_Pirenne "Henri Pirenne")[82] disputes this saying
that the coronation "was not in any sense explained by the fact that at this
moment a woman was reigning in Constantinople". Nonetheless, the Pope took the
extraordinary step of creating one. The papacy had since 727 been in conflict
with Irene's predecessors in Constantinople over a number of issues, chiefly
the continued Byzantine adherence to the doctrine of
[iconoclasm](/wiki/Iconoclasm "Iconoclasm"), the destruction of Christian
images; while from 750, the secular power of the Byzantine Empire in central
Italy had been nullified.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Couronnement_d%27un_prince_-
_Sacramentaire_de_Charles_le_Chauve_Lat1141_f2v.jpg/220px-
Couronnement_d%27un_prince_-
_Sacramentaire_de_Charles_le_Chauve_Lat1141_f2v.jpg)](/wiki/File:Couronnement_d%27un_prince_-
_Sacramentaire_de_Charles_le_Chauve_Lat1141_f2v.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Couronnement_d%27un_prince_-
_Sacramentaire_de_Charles_le_Chauve_Lat1141_f2v.jpg "Enlarge")

Coronation of an idealised king, depicted in the Sacramentary of [Charles the
Bald](/wiki/Charles_the_Bald "Charles the Bald") (about 870)

By bestowing the Imperial crown upon Charlemagne, the Pope arrogated to
himself "the right to appoint ... the Emperor of the Romans, ... establishing
the imperial crown as his own personal gift but simultaneously granting
himself implicit superiority over the Emperor whom he had created." And
"because the Byzantines had proved so unsatisfactory from every point of
view—political, military and doctrinal—he would select a westerner: the one
man who by his wisdom and statesmanship and the vastness of his dominions ...
stood out head and shoulders above his contemporaries."[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

With Charlemagne's coronation, therefore, "the Roman Empire remained, so far
as either of them [Charlemagne and Leo] were concerned, one and indivisible,
with Charles as its Emperor", though there can have been "little doubt that
the coronation, with all that it implied, would be furiously contested in
Constantinople".[83]

[Alcuin](/wiki/Alcuin "Alcuin") writes hopefully in his letters of an
_Imperium Christianum_ ("Christian Empire"), wherein, "just as the inhabitants
of the [Roman Empire] had been united by a common Roman citizenship",
presumably this new empire would be united by a common Christian faith.[78]
This writes the view of Pirenne when he says "Charles was the Emperor of the
_ecclesia_ as the Pope conceived it, of the Roman Church, regarded as the
universal Church".[84] The _Imperium Christianum_ was further supported at a
number of [synods](/wiki/Synod "Synod") all across the Europe by Paulinus of
Aquileia.[85]

What is known, from the Byzantine chronicler
[Theophanes](/wiki/Theophanes_the_Confessor "Theophanes the Confessor"),[86]
is that Charlemagne's reaction to his coronation was to take the initial steps
towards securing the Constantinopolitan throne by sending envoys of marriage
to Irene, and that Irene reacted somewhat favourably to them.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Raphael_Charlemagne.jpg/250px-
Raphael_Charlemagne.jpg)](/wiki/File:Raphael_Charlemagne.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Raphael_Charlemagne.jpg "Enlarge")

_[The Coronation of Charlemagne](/wiki/The_Coronation_of_Charlemagne "The
Coronation of Charlemagne")_ , by assistants of [Raphael](/wiki/Raphael
"Raphael"), circa 1516–1517.

It is important to distinguish between the universalist and localist
conceptions of the empire, which remain controversial among historians.
According to the former, the empire was a universal monarchy, a "commonwealth
of the whole world, whose sublime unity transcended every minor distinction";
and the emperor "was entitled to the obedience of Christendom". According to
the latter, the emperor had no ambition for universal dominion; his realm was
limited in the same way as that of every other ruler; and when he made more
far-reaching claims his object was normally to ward off the attacks either of
the Pope or of the Byzantine emperor. According to this view, also, the origin
of the empire is to be explained by specific local circumstances rather than
by overarching theories.[87]

According to Ohnsorge, for a long time it had been the custom of Byzantium to
designate the German princes as spiritual "sons" of the Byzantines. What might
have been acceptable in the fifth century had become provoking and insulting
to the Franks in the eighth century. Charles came to believe that the Roman
emperor, who claimed to head the world hierarchy of states, in reality was no
greater than Charles himself, a king as other kings, since beginning in 629 he
had entitled himself "Basileus" (translated literally as "king"). Ohnsorge
finds it significant that the chief wax seal of Charles, which bore only the
inscription: "Christe, protege Carolum regem Francorum [Christ, protect
Charles, king of the Franks], was used from 772 to 813, even during the
imperial period and was not replaced by a special imperial seal; indicating
that Charles felt himself to be just the king of the Franks. Finally, Ohnsorge
points out that in the spring of 813 at Aachen Charles crowned his only
surviving son, Louis, as emperor without recourse to Rome with only the
acclamation of his Franks. The form in which this acclamation was offered was
Frankish-Christian rather than Roman. This implies both independence from Rome
and a Frankish (non-Roman) understanding of empire.[88]

### Imperial
title[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=31 "Edit
section: Imperial title")]

Charlemagne used these circumstances to claim that he was the renewer of the
Roman Empire, which had declined under the [Byzantines](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire
"Byzantine Empire"). In his official charters, Charles preferred the style
_Karolus serenissimus Augustus a Deo coronatus magnus pacificus imperator
Romanum gubernans imperium_[89] ("Charles, most serene Augustus crowned by
God, the great, peaceful emperor ruling the Roman empire") to the more direct
_Imperator Romanorum_ ("Emperor of the Romans").

The title of Emperor remained in the Carolingian family for years to come, but
divisions of territory and in-fighting over supremacy of the Frankish state
weakened its significance.[90] The papacy itself never forgot the title nor
abandoned the right to bestow it. When the family of Charles ceased to produce
worthy heirs, the Pope gladly crowned whichever Italian magnate could best
protect him from his local enemies. The empire would remain in continuous
existence for nearly a millennium, as the Holy Roman Empire, a true imperial
successor to Charles.[91]

### Imperial
diplomacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=32 "Edit
section: Imperial diplomacy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Europe_in_814%2C_Charlemagne%2C_Krum%2C_Nicephorus_I.png/300px-
Europe_in_814%2C_Charlemagne%2C_Krum%2C_Nicephorus_I.png)](/wiki/File:Europe_in_814,_Charlemagne,_Krum,_Nicephorus_I.png)

[](/wiki/File:Europe_in_814,_Charlemagne,_Krum,_Nicephorus_I.png "Enlarge")

Europe around 814

The [iconoclasm of the Byzantine](/wiki/Iconoclasm_\(Byzantine\) "Iconoclasm
\(Byzantine\)") [Isaurian Dynasty](/wiki/Leo_III_the_Isaurian "Leo III the
Isaurian") was endorsed by the Franks.[92] The [Second Council of
Nicaea](/wiki/Second_Council_of_Nicaea "Second Council of Nicaea")
reintroduced the veneration of icons under Empress
[Irene](/wiki/Byzantine_Empress_Irene "Byzantine Empress Irene"). The council
was not recognised by Charlemagne since no Frankish emissaries had been
invited, even though Charlemagne ruled more than three provinces of the old
Roman empire and was considered equal in rank to the Byzantine emperor. And
while the Pope supported the reintroduction of the iconic veneration, he
politically digressed from Byzantium.[92] He certainly desired to increase the
influence of the papacy, to honour his saviour Charlemagne, and to solve the
constitutional issues then most troubling to European jurists in an era when
Rome was not in the hands of an emperor. Thus, Charlemagne's assumption of the
imperial title was not a usurpation in the eyes of the Franks or Italians. It
was, however, seen as such in Byzantium, where it was protested by Irene and
her successor [Nikephoros I](/wiki/Nikephoros_I "Nikephoros I")—neither of
whom had any great effect in enforcing their protests.

The Byzantines, however, still held several territories in Italy: Venice (what
was left of the [Exarchate of Ravenna](/wiki/Exarchate_of_Ravenna "Exarchate
of Ravenna")), [Reggio](/wiki/Reggio_Calabria "Reggio Calabria") (in
[Calabria](/wiki/Calabria "Calabria")), [Brindisi](/wiki/Brindisi "Brindisi")
(in [Apulia](/wiki/Apulia "Apulia")), and [Naples](/wiki/Naples "Naples") (the
_[Ducatus Neapolitanus](/wiki/Ducatus_Neapolitanus "Ducatus Neapolitanus")_).
These regions remained outside of Frankish hands until 804, when the
Venetians, torn by infighting, transferred their allegiance to the Iron Crown
of Pippin, Charles' son. The _[Pax Nicephori](/wiki/Pax_Nicephori "Pax
Nicephori")_ ended. Nicephorus ravaged the coasts with a fleet, initiating the
only instance of war between the Byzantines and the Franks. The conflict
lasted until 810, when the pro-Byzantine party in Venice gave their city back
to the Byzantine Emperor, and the two emperors of Europe made peace:
Charlemagne received the [Istrian](/wiki/Istria "Istria") peninsula and in 812
the emperor [Michael I Rangabe](/wiki/Michael_I_Rangabe "Michael I Rangabe")
recognised his status as Emperor,[93] although not necessarily as "Emperor of
the Romans".[94]

### Danish
attacks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Danish attacks")]

After the conquest of Nordalbingia, the Frankish frontier was brought into
contact with Scandinavia. The [pagan](/wiki/Norse_paganism "Norse paganism")
Danes, "a race almost unknown to his ancestors, but destined to be only too
well known to his sons" as [Charles Oman](/wiki/Charles_Oman "Charles Oman")
described them, inhabiting the [Jutland](/wiki/Jutland "Jutland") peninsula,
had heard many stories from [Widukind](/wiki/Widukind "Widukind") and his
allies who had taken refuge with them about the dangers of the Franks and the
fury which their Christian king could direct against pagan neighbours.

In 808, the king of the Danes, [Godfred](/wiki/Gudfred "Gudfred"), built the
vast [Danevirke](/wiki/Danevirke "Danevirke") across the isthmus of
[Schleswig](/wiki/Schleswig "Schleswig"). This defence, last employed in the
Danish-Prussian War of 1864, was at its beginning a 30 km (19 mi) long
earthenwork rampart. The Danevirke protected Danish land and gave Godfred the
opportunity to harass [Frisia](/wiki/Frisia "Frisia") and
[Flanders](/wiki/Flanders "Flanders") with pirate raids. He also subdued the
Frank-allied Wiltzes and fought the Abotrites.

Godfred invaded Frisia, joked of visiting Aachen, but was murdered before he
could do any more, either by a Frankish assassin or by one of his own men.
Godfred was succeeded by his nephew [Hemming](/wiki/King_Hemming "King
Hemming"), who concluded the [Treaty of Heiligen](/wiki/Treaty_of_Heiligen
"Treaty of Heiligen") with Charlemagne in late 811.

### Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=34 "Edit
section: Death")]

See also: [Testament of Charlemagne](/wiki/Testament_of_Charlemagne "Testament
of Charlemagne")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Shroud_of_Charlemagne_manufactured_in_Constantinople_814.jpg/220px-
Shroud_of_Charlemagne_manufactured_in_Constantinople_814.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shroud_of_Charlemagne_manufactured_in_Constantinople_814.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Shroud_of_Charlemagne_manufactured_in_Constantinople_814.jpg
"Enlarge")

Portion of the 814 death [shroud](/wiki/Shroud "Shroud") of Charlemagne. It
represents a [quadriga](/wiki/Quadriga "Quadriga") and was manufactured in
[Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Karlsschrein_front_side_left.jpg/220px-
Karlsschrein_front_side_left.jpg)](/wiki/File:Karlsschrein_front_side_left.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Karlsschrein_front_side_left.jpg "Enlarge")

[Frederick II's](/wiki/Frederick_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Frederick II, Holy
Roman Emperor") gold and silver casket for Charlemagne, the
[Karlsschrein](/wiki/Karlsschrein "Karlsschrein")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/AachenerDomSarg.jpg/220px-
AachenerDomSarg.jpg)](/wiki/File:AachenerDomSarg.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:AachenerDomSarg.jpg "Enlarge")

[Persephone sarcophagus](/wiki/Persephone_sarcophagus "Persephone
sarcophagus") of Charlemagne

In 813, Charlemagne called [Louis the Pious](/wiki/Louis_the_Pious "Louis the
Pious"), king of [Aquitaine](/wiki/Aquitaine "Aquitaine"), his only surviving
legitimate son, to his court. There Charlemagne crowned his son as co-emperor
and sent him back to Aquitaine. He then spent the autumn hunting before
returning to Aachen on 1 November. In January, he fell ill with
[pleurisy](/wiki/Pleurisy "Pleurisy").[95] In deep depression (mostly because
many of his plans were not yet realised), he took to his bed on 21 January and
as [Einhard](/wiki/Einhard "Einhard") tells it:

> He died January twenty-eighth, the seventh day from the time that he took to
> his bed, at nine o'clock in the morning, after partaking of the [Holy
> Communion](/wiki/Holy_Communion "Holy Communion"), in the seventy-second
> year of his age and the forty-seventh of his reign.

He was buried that same day, in [Aachen Cathedral](/wiki/Aachen_Cathedral
"Aachen Cathedral"), although the cold weather and the nature of his illness
made such a hurried burial unnecessary. The earliest surviving
_[planctus](/wiki/Planctus "Planctus")_ , the _[Planctus de obitu
Karoli](/wiki/Planctus_de_obitu_Karoli "Planctus de obitu Karoli")_ , was
composed by a monk of [Bobbio](/wiki/Bobbio_Abbey "Bobbio Abbey"), which he
had patronised.[96] A later story, told by Otho of Lomello, Count of the
Palace at Aachen in the time of [Otto III](/wiki/Otto_III,_Holy_Roman_Emperor
"Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor"), would claim that he and Emperor Otto had
discovered Charlemagne's tomb: the emperor, they claimed, was seated upon a
throne, wearing a crown and holding a sceptre, his flesh almost entirely
incorrupt. In 1165, [Frederick I](/wiki/Frederick_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor
"Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor") re-opened the tomb again and placed the
emperor in a sarcophagus beneath the floor of the cathedral.[97] In 1215
[Frederick II](/wiki/Frederick_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Frederick II, Holy
Roman Emperor") re-interred him in a casket made of gold and silver.

Charlemagne's death emotionally affected many of his subjects, particularly
those of the literary clique who had surrounded him at [Aachen](/wiki/Aachen
"Aachen"). An anonymous monk of Bobbio lamented:[98]

> From the lands where the sun rises to western shores, people are crying and
> wailing ... the Franks, the Romans, all Christians, are stung with mourning
> and great worry ... the young and old, glorious nobles, all lament the loss
> of their Caesar ... the world laments the death of Charles ... O Christ, you
> who govern the heavenly host, grant a peaceful place to Charles in your
> kingdom. Alas for miserable me.

Louis succeeded him as Charles had intended. He left a
[testament](/wiki/The_Testament_of_Charlemagne "The Testament of Charlemagne")
allocating his assets in 811 that was not updated prior to his death. His
empire lasted only another generation in its entirety; its division, according
to custom, between Louis's own sons after their father's death laid the
foundation for the modern states of Germany and France.[99]

## Administration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Administration")]

As an administrator, Charlemagne stands out for his many reforms:
[monetary](/wiki/Monetary "Monetary"), governmental, military, cultural and
[ecclesiastical](/wiki/Ecclesiastic "Ecclesiastic"). He is the main
protagonist of the "Carolingian Renaissance".

### Military[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=36
"Edit section: Military")]

Charlemagne's success rested primarily on novel [siege](/wiki/Siege "Siege")
technologies and excellent logistics[100] rather than the long-claimed
"[cavalry](/wiki/Heavy_cavalry "Heavy cavalry") revolution" led by [Charles
Martel](/wiki/Charles_Martel "Charles Martel") in 730s. However, the
[stirrup](/wiki/Stirrup "Stirrup"), which made the "shock cavalry"
[lance](/wiki/Lance "Lance") charge possible, was not introduced to the
Frankish kingdom until the late eighth century.[101]

Horses were used extensively by the Frankish military, because horses provided
a quick, long-distance method of [transporting troops](/wiki/Mounted_infantry
"Mounted infantry"), which was critical to building and maintaining the large
empire.[101]

### Economic and monetary
reforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=37 "Edit
section: Economic and monetary reforms")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Karldergrossesignatur.svg/400px-
Karldergrossesignatur.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Karldergrossesignatur.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Karldergrossesignatur.svg "Enlarge")

[Monogram](/wiki/Monogram "Monogram") of Charlemagne, including [signum
manus](/wiki/Signum_manus "Signum manus"), from the subscription of a royal
diploma: _Signum_ (monogr.: KAROLVS) _Karoli gloriosissimi regis_

Charlemagne had an important role in determining Europe's immediate economic
future. Pursuing his father's reforms, Charlemagne abolished the monetary
system based on the gold _[sou](/wiki/Solidus_\(coin\) "Solidus \(coin\)")_.
Instead he and the [Anglo-Saxon King](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_monarchs "Anglo-Saxon
monarchs") [Offa of Mercia](/wiki/Offa_of_Mercia "Offa of Mercia") took up
Pippin's system for pragmatic reasons, notably a shortage of the metal.

The gold shortage was a direct consequence of the conclusion of peace with
Byzantium, which resulted in ceding Venice and Sicily to the East and losing
their trade routes to Africa. The resulting standardisation economically
harmonised and unified the complex array of currencies that had been in use at
the commencement of his reign, thus simplifying trade and commerce.

Charlemagne established a new standard, the _[livre
carolinienne](/wiki/French_livre "French livre")_ (from the Latin
_[libra](/wiki/Ancient_Roman_units_of_measurement "Ancient Roman units of
measurement")_ , the modern [pound](/wiki/Pound_\(currency\) "Pound
\(currency\)")), which was based upon a pound of silver—a unit of both money
and weight—worth 20 sous (from the Latin _[solidus](/wiki/Solidus_\(coin\)
"Solidus \(coin\)")_ [which was primarily an accounting device and never
actually minted], the modern [shilling](/wiki/Shilling "Shilling")) or 240
_[deniers](/wiki/Denier_\(coin\) "Denier \(coin\)")_ (from the Latin
_[denarius](/wiki/Denarius "Denarius")_ , the modern [penny](/wiki/Penny
"Penny")). During this period, the _livre_ and the _sou_ were counting units;
only the _denier_ was a coin of the realm.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Charlemagne_denier_Tours_793_to_812.jpg/170px-
Charlemagne_denier_Tours_793_to_812.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_denier_Tours_793_to_812.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_denier_Tours_793_to_812.jpg "Enlarge")

Denier from the era of Charlemagne, [Tours](/wiki/Tours "Tours"), 793–812

Charlemagne instituted principles for [accounting practice](/wiki/Accountancy
"Accountancy") by means of the [Capitulare de
villis](/wiki/Capitulare_de_villis "Capitulare de villis") of 802, which laid
down strict rules for the way in which incomes and expenses were to be
recorded.

Charlemagne applied this system to much of the European continent, and Offa's
standard was voluntarily adopted by much of England. After Charlemagne's
death, continental coinage degraded, and most of Europe resorted to using the
continued high-quality English coin until about 1100.

### Jews in Charlemagne's
realm[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=38 "Edit
section: Jews in Charlemagne's realm")]

Early in Charlemagne's rule he tacitly allowed Jews to monopolise money
lending. Then lending of money for interest was proscribed in 814, because it
violated Church law. Charlemagne introduced the _[Capitulary for the
Jews](/wiki/Capitulary_for_the_Jews "Capitulary for the Jews")_ , a
prohibition on Jews engaging in money-lending due to the religious convictions
of the majority of his constituents, in essence banning it across the board, a
reversal of his earlier recorded general policy.[102] In addition to this
broad change, Charlemagne also performed a significant number of microeconomic
reforms, such as direct control of prices and levies on certain goods and
commodities.

His _Capitulary for the Jews_ , however, was not representative of his overall
economic relationship or attitude towards the Frankish Jews, and certainly not
his earlier relationship with them, which evolved over his life. His personal
physician for example was Jewish,[103] he employed at least one Jew for
diplomatic missions and[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Isaac was his personal representative to the
Muslim caliphate of Baghdad. Letters have been credited to him that invited
Jews to settle in his kingdom.[104][105][106]

### Education
reforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=39 "Edit
section: Education reforms")]

Part of Charlemagne's success as a warrior, an administrator and ruler can be
traced to his admiration for learning and education. His reign are often
referred to as the [Carolingian Renaissance](/wiki/Carolingian_Renaissance
"Carolingian Renaissance") because of the flowering of scholarship,
literature, art and architecture that characterise it. Charlemagne came into
contact with the culture and learning of other countries (especially Moorish
Spain, Anglo-Saxon England,[107] and Lombard Italy) due to his vast conquests.
He greatly increased the provision of monastic schools and scriptoria (centres
for book-copying) in Francia.

Most of the presently surviving works of classical Latin were copied and
preserved by Carolingian scholars. Indeed, the earliest manuscripts available
for many ancient texts are Carolingian. It is almost certain that a text which
survived to the Carolingian age survives still.

The pan-European nature of Charlemagne's influence is indicated by the origins
of many of the men who worked for him: [Alcuin](/wiki/Alcuin "Alcuin"), an
[Anglo-Saxon](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons "Anglo-Saxons") from [York](/wiki/York
"York"); [Theodulf](/wiki/Theodulf "Theodulf"), a [Visigoth](/wiki/Visigoths
"Visigoths"), probably from [Septimania](/wiki/Septimania "Septimania"); [Paul
the Deacon](/wiki/Paul_the_Deacon "Paul the Deacon"), Lombard;
[Italians](/wiki/Italians "Italians") [Peter of Pisa](/wiki/Peter_of_Pisa
"Peter of Pisa") and [Paulinus of Aquileia](/wiki/Saint_Paulinus_II "Saint
Paulinus II"); and Franks [Angilbert](/wiki/Angilbert "Angilbert"), Angilram,
[Einhard](/wiki/Einhard "Einhard") and [Waldo of
Reichenau](/wiki/Waldo_of_Reichenau "Waldo of Reichenau").

Charlemagne promoted the [liberal arts](/wiki/Liberal_arts "Liberal arts") at
court, ordering that his children and grandchildren be well-educated, and even
studying himself (in a time when even leaders who promoted education did not
take time to learn themselves) under the tutelage of Peter of Pisa, from whom
he learned grammar; Alcuin, with whom he studied rhetoric, dialectic (logic),
and astronomy (he was particularly interested in the movements of the stars);
and Einhard, who tutored him in arithmetic.[108]

His great scholarly failure, as Einhard relates, was his inability to write:
when in his old age he attempted to learn—practising the formation of letters
in his bed during his free time on books and wax tablets he hid under his
pillow—"his effort came too late in life and achieved little success", and his
ability to read – which Einhard is silent about, and which no contemporary
source supports—has also been called into question.[108]

In 800, Charlemagne enlarged the hostel at the [Muristan](/wiki/Muristan
"Muristan") in [Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem "Jerusalem") and added a library to
it. He certainly had not been personally in Jerusalem.[109][110]

### Church
reforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=40 "Edit
section: Church reforms")]

See also: [Charlemagne and church music](/wiki/Charlemagne_and_church_music
"Charlemagne and church music")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Aachen_Cathedral_top_floor.jpg/220px-
Aachen_Cathedral_top_floor.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aachen_Cathedral_top_floor.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aachen_Cathedral_top_floor.jpg "Enlarge")

[Charlemagne's chapel](/wiki/Palatine_Chapel_in_Aachen "Palatine Chapel in
Aachen") at [Aachen Cathedral](/wiki/Aachen_Cathedral "Aachen Cathedral").

Unlike his father, Pippin, and uncle, Carloman, Charlemagne expanded the
reform Church's programme. The deepening of the spiritual life was later to be
seen as central to public policy and royal governance. His reform focused on
strengthening the church's power structure, improving clergy's skill and moral
quality, standardising liturgical practices, improvements on the basic tenets
of the faith and the rooting out of paganism. His authority extended over
church and state. He could discipline clerics, control ecclesiastical property
and define orthodox doctrine. Despite the harsh legislation and sudden change,
he had developed support from clergy who approved his desire to deepen the
piety and morals of his subjects.[111]

In 809–810, Charlemagne called a church council in [Aachen](/wiki/Aachen
"Aachen"), which confirmed the unanimous belief in the West that the Holy
Spirit proceeds from the Father and the Son (_ex
Patre[Filioque](/wiki/Filioque "Filioque")_) and sanctioned inclusion in the
[Nicene Creed](/wiki/Nicene_Creed "Nicene Creed") of the phrase _Filioque_
(and the Son). For this Charlemagne sought the approval of [Pope Leo
III](/wiki/Pope_Leo_III "Pope Leo III"). The Pope, while affirming the
doctrine and approving its use in teaching, opposed its inclusion in the text
of the Creed as adopted in the 381 [First Council of
Constantinople](/wiki/First_Council_of_Constantinople "First Council of
Constantinople"). This spoke of the procession of the Holy Spirit from the
Father, without adding phrases such as "and the Son", "through the Son", or
"alone". Stressing his opposition, the Pope had the original text inscribed in
Greek and Latin on two heavy shields that were displayed in [Saint Peter's
Basilica](/wiki/Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica "Saint Peter's
Basilica").[112][113][114]

### Writing
reforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=41 "Edit
section: Writing reforms")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Codexaureus_04.jpg/170px-
Codexaureus_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Codexaureus_04.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Codexaureus_04.jpg "Enlarge")

Page from the [Lorsch Gospels](/wiki/Lorsch_Gospels "Lorsch Gospels") of
Charlemagne's reign

During Charles' reign, the [Roman half uncial](/wiki/Uncial "Uncial") script
and its cursive version, which had given rise to various continental
[minuscule](/wiki/Minuscule_cursive "Minuscule cursive") scripts, were
combined with features from the [insular scripts](/wiki/Insular_script
"Insular script") in use in Irish and English monasteries. [Carolingian
minuscule](/wiki/Carolingian_minuscule "Carolingian minuscule") was created
partly under the patronage of Charlemagne. [Alcuin](/wiki/Alcuin "Alcuin"),
who ran the palace school and [scriptorium](/wiki/Scriptorium "Scriptorium")
at Aachen, was probably a chief influence.

The revolutionary character of the Carolingian reform, however, can be over-
emphasised; efforts at taming Merovingian and Germanic influence had been
underway before Alcuin arrived at Aachen. The new minuscule was disseminated
first from Aachen and later from the influential scriptorium at
[Tours](/wiki/Tours "Tours"), where Alcuin retired as an abbot.

### Political
reforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=42 "Edit
section: Political reforms")]

Charlemagne engaged in many reforms of Frankish governance, while continuing
many traditional practices, such as the division of the kingdom among
sons.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

#### Organisation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=43
"Edit section: Organisation")]

Main article: [Government of the Carolingian
Empire](/wiki/Government_of_the_Carolingian_Empire "Government of the
Carolingian Empire")

The Carolingian king exercised the _[bannum](/wiki/Bannum "Bannum")_ , the
right to rule and command. He had supreme jurisdiction in judicial matters,
made legislation, led the army, and protected both the Church and the poor.
His administration was an attempt to organise the kingdom, church and nobility
around him. However, the effort was heavily dependent upon the efficiency,
loyalty, and support of his subjects.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

#### Divisio
regnorum[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=44 "Edit
section: Divisio regnorum")]

In 806, Charlemagne first made provision for the traditional division of the
empire on his death. For Charles the Younger he designated Austrasia and
Neustria, Saxony, Burgundy and [Thuringia](/wiki/Thuringia "Thuringia"). To
Pippin he gave Italy, Bavaria and [Swabia](/wiki/Swabia "Swabia"). Louis
received Aquitaine, the Spanish March and [Provence](/wiki/Provence
"Provence"). The imperial title was not mentioned, which led to the suggestion
that, at that particular time, Charlemagne regarded the title as an honorary
achievement that held no hereditary significance.

Pepin died in 810 and Charles in 811. Charlemagne then reconsidered the
matter, and in 813, crowned his youngest son, Louis, co-emperor and co-King of
the Franks, granting him a half-share of the empire and the rest upon
Charlemagne's own death. The only part of the Empire that Louis was not
promised was Italy, which Charlemagne specifically bestowed upon Pippin's
illegitimate son [Bernard](/wiki/Bernard_of_Italy "Bernard of
Italy").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Personality[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=45
"Edit section: Personality")]

### Manner[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=46 "Edit
section: Manner")]

Einhard tells in his twenty-fourth chapter:

> Charles was temperate in eating, and particularly so in drinking, for he
> abominated drunkenness in anybody, much more in himself and those of his
> household; but he could not easily abstain from food, and often complained
> that fasts injured his health. He very rarely gave entertainments, only on
> great feast-days, and then to large numbers of people. His meals ordinarily
> consisted of four courses, not counting the roast, which his huntsmen used
> to bring in on the spit; he was more fond of this than of any other dish.
> While at table, he listened to reading or music. The subjects of the
> readings were the stories and deeds of olden time: he was fond, too, of St.
> Augustine's books, and especially of the one entitled "The City of
> God."[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
> needed")_]

Charlemagne threw grand banquets and feasts for special occasions such as
religious holidays and four of his weddings. When he was not working, he loved
Christian books, horseback riding, swimming, bathing in natural hot springs
with his friends and family, and hunting.[115] Franks were well known for
horsemanship and hunting skills.[115] Charles was a light sleeper and would
stay in his bed chambers for entire days at a time due to restless nights.
During these days, he would not get out of bed when a quarrel occurred in his
kingdom. Instead of handling business in a professional manner, he called all
members of the situation into his bedroom to be given orders. Einhard tells
again in the twenty fourth chapter: "In summer after the midday meal, he would
eat some fruit, drain a single cup, put off his clothes and shoes, just as he
did for the night, and rest for two or three hours. He was in the habit of
awaking and rising from bed four or five times during the night."[115]

### Language[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=47
"Edit section: Language")]

Main article: [Theodiscus](/wiki/Theodiscus "Theodiscus")

By Charlemagne's time the French vernacular had already diverged significantly
from Latin. This is evidenced by one of the regulations of the [Council of
Tours](/wiki/Council_of_Tours "Council of Tours") (813), which required that
parish priests preach either in the "rusticam Romanam linguam" (Romance) or
"Theotiscam" (the Germanic vernacular) rather than in Latin. The goal of this
rule was to make sermons comprehensible to the common people.[116] Charlemagne
himself probably spoke a Rhenish [Franconian](/wiki/Franconian_languages
"Franconian languages") dialect.[117][118][119]

He also spoke [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") and had at least some understanding
of Greek, according to Einhard (_Grecam vero melius intellegere quam
pronuntiare poterat_ , "he could understand Greek better than he could speak
it").[120]

The largely fictional account of Charlemagne's Iberian campaigns by [Pseudo-
Turpin](/wiki/Pseudo-Turpin "Pseudo-Turpin"), written some three centuries
after his death, gave rise to the legend that the king also spoke
[Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic").[121]

### Appearance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=48
"Edit section: Appearance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Charles_Marville%2C_H%C3%B4tel_Carnavalet%2C_statue_of_Charlemagne%2C_ca._1853%E2%80%9370.jpg/220px-
Charles_Marville%2C_H%C3%B4tel_Carnavalet%2C_statue_of_Charlemagne%2C_ca._1853%E2%80%9370.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charles_Marville,_H%C3%B4tel_Carnavalet,_statue_of_Charlemagne,_ca._1853%E2%80%9370.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charles_Marville,_H%C3%B4tel_Carnavalet,_statue_of_Charlemagne,_ca._1853%E2%80%9370.jpg
"Enlarge")

The Carolingian-era [equestrian
statuette](/wiki/Equestrian_statuette_of_Charlemagne "Equestrian statuette of
Charlemagne") thought to represent Charlemagne (from [Metz
Cathedral](/wiki/Metz_Cathedral "Metz Cathedral"), now in the Louvre)

Charlemagne's personal appearance is known from a good description by Einhard
after his death in the biography _[Vita Karoli Magni](/wiki/Vita_Karoli_Magni
"Vita Karoli Magni")_. Einhard states:[122]

> He was heavily built, sturdy, and of considerable stature, although not
> exceptionally so, since his height was seven times the length of his own
> foot. He had a round head, large and lively eyes, a slightly larger nose
> than usual, white but still attractive hair, a bright and cheerful
> expression, a short and fat neck, and he enjoyed good health, except for the
> fevers that affected him in the last few years of his life. Towards the end,
> he dragged one leg. Even then, he stubbornly did what he wanted and refused
> to listen to doctors, indeed he detested them, because they wanted to
> persuade him to stop eating roast meat, as was his wont, and to be content
> with boiled meat.

The physical portrait provided by Einhard is confirmed by contemporary
depictions such as coins and his 8-inch (20 cm) [bronze
statuette](/wiki/Equestrian_statuette_of_Charlemagne "Equestrian statuette of
Charlemagne") kept in the [Louvre](/wiki/Louvre "Louvre"). In 1861,
Charlemagne's tomb was opened by scientists who reconstructed his skeleton and
estimated it to be measured 1.95 metres (6 ft 5 in).[123] An estimate of his
height from an [X-ray](/wiki/Radiology "Radiology") and [CT
scan](/wiki/CT_scan "CT scan") of his [tibia](/wiki/Tibia "Tibia") performed
in 2010 is 1.84 metres (6 ft 0 in). This puts him in the 99th
[percentile](/wiki/Percentile "Percentile") of height for his period, given
that average male height of his time was 1.69 metres (5 ft 7 in). The width of
the bone suggested he was [gracile](/wiki/Gracility "Gracility") but not
[robust](/wiki/Robustness_\(morphology\) "Robustness \(morphology\)") in body
build.[124]

### Dress[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=49 "Edit
section: Dress")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Charles_Ier_le_Grand_ou_Charlemagne.jpg/220px-
Charles_Ier_le_Grand_ou_Charlemagne.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charles_Ier_le_Grand_ou_Charlemagne.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charles_Ier_le_Grand_ou_Charlemagne.jpg "Enlarge")

In the Bibliothèque Nationale de France

Charlemagne wore the traditional [costume of the Frankish
people](/wiki/Early_medieval_European_dress "Early medieval European dress"),
described by Einhard thus:[125]

> He used to wear the national, that is to say, the Frank, dress—next his skin
> a linen shirt and linen breeches, and above these a tunic fringed with silk;
> while hose fastened by bands covered his lower limbs, and shoes his feet,
> and he protected his shoulders and chest in winter by a close-fitting coat
> of otter or marten skins.

He wore a blue cloak and always carried a sword typically of a golden or
silver hilt. He wore fancy jewelled swords to banquets or ambassadorial
receptions. Nevertheless:[125]

> He despised foreign costumes, however handsome, and never allowed himself to
> be robed in them, except twice in Rome, when he donned the Roman tunic,
> chlamys, and shoes; the first time at the request of Pope Hadrian, the
> second to gratify Leo, Hadrian's successor.

On great feast days, he wore embroidery and jewels on his clothing and shoes.
He had a golden buckle for his cloak on such occasions and would appear with
his great [diadem](/wiki/Diadem_\(personal_wear\) "Diadem \(personal wear\)"),
but he despised such apparel, according to Einhard and usually dressed like
the common people.[125]

### Homes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=50 "Edit
section: Homes")]

Charlemagne had residences across his kingdom, including numerous private
estates that were governed in accordance with the [Capitulare de
villis](/wiki/Capitulare_de_villis "Capitulare de villis"). A 9th century
document detailing the inventory of an estate at Asnapium listed amounts of
livestock, plants and vegetables and kitchenware including cauldrons, drinking
cups, brass kettles and firewood. The manor contained seventeen houses built
inside the courtyard for nobles and family members and was separated from its
supporting villas.[126]

## Family[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=51 "Edit
section: Family")]

### Marriages and
heirs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=52 "Edit
section: Marriages and heirs")]

Charlemagne had eighteen children with eight of his ten known wives or
concubines.[127] Nonetheless, he had only four legitimate grandsons, the four
sons of his fourth son, Louis. In addition, he had a grandson ([Bernard of
Italy](/wiki/Bernard_of_Italy "Bernard of Italy"), the only son of his third
son, [Pippin of Italy](/wiki/Pippin_of_Italy "Pippin of Italy")), who was
illegitimate, but included in the line of inheritance. Among his descendants
are several royal dynasties, including the [Habsburg](/wiki/Habsburg
"Habsburg"), [Capetian](/wiki/Capetian "Capetian") and
[Plantagenet](/wiki/Plantagenet "Plantagenet") dynasties.

Start date | Marriages and heirs | Concubinages and illegitimate children  
---|---|---  
c.768 | His first relationship was with [Himiltrude](/wiki/Himiltrude "Himiltrude"). The nature of this relationship is variously described as [concubinage](/wiki/Concubine "Concubine"), a legal marriage, or a [Friedelehe](/wiki/Friedelehe "Friedelehe").[128] (Charlemagne put her aside when he married Desiderata.) The union with Himiltrude produced a son: 

  * [Pippin the Hunchback](/wiki/Pippin_the_Hunchback "Pippin the Hunchback") (ca. 769–811)

|  
c. 770 | After her, his first wife was [Desiderata](/wiki/Desiderata,_wife_of_Charlemagne "Desiderata, wife of Charlemagne"), daughter of [Desiderius](/wiki/Desiderius "Desiderius"), king of the [Lombards](/wiki/Lombards "Lombards"); married in 770, annulled in 771. |

  * [Charles the Younger](/wiki/Charles_the_Younger "Charles the Younger") (ca. 772–4 December 811), Duke of Maine, and crowned [King of the Franks](/wiki/King_of_the_Franks "King of the Franks") on 25 December 800
  * [Carloman, renamed Pippin](/wiki/Pepin_of_Italy "Pepin of Italy") (April 773–8 July 810), [King of Italy](/wiki/King_of_Italy "King of Italy")
  * Adalhaid (774), who was born whilst her parents were on campaign in Italy. She was sent back to Francia, but died before reaching Lyons

  * [Louis](/wiki/Louis_the_Pious "Louis the Pious") (778–20 June 840), twin of Lothair, [King of Aquitaine](/wiki/King_of_Aquitaine "King of Aquitaine") since 781, crowned [King of the Franks/co-emperor](/wiki/List_of_Frankish_kings "List of Frankish kings") in 813, senior Emperor from 814

|  
c. 773 |  | His first known concubine was Gersuinda. By her he had: 

  * Adaltrude (b.774)

  
c. 774 |  | His second known concubine was Madelgard. By her he had:
