## Name[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=54 "Edit
section: Name")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg/220px-
Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg "Enlarge")

[Bust of Charlemagne](/wiki/Bust_of_Charlemagne "Bust of Charlemagne"),
located at [Aachen Cathedral Treasury](/wiki/Aachen_Cathedral_Treasury "Aachen
Cathedral Treasury")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Charlemagne_arm_at_Cathedral_Treasury_Aachen_Germany.jpg/170px-
Charlemagne_arm_at_Cathedral_Treasury_Aachen_Germany.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_arm_at_Cathedral_Treasury_Aachen_Germany.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charlemagne_arm_at_Cathedral_Treasury_Aachen_Germany.jpg
"Enlarge")

Arm reliquary of Charlemagne at Aachen Cathedral Treasury

He was named _Charles_ in French and English, _Carolus_ in Latin, after his
grandfather, [Charles Martel](/wiki/Charles_Martel "Charles Martel"). Later
Old French historians dubbed him _Charles le Magne_ (Charles the Great),[130]
becoming Charlemagne in English after the [Norman conquest of
England](/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England "Norman conquest of England"). The
epithet Carolus Magnus was widely used, leading to numerous translations into
many languages of Europe. He was known in German as Karl der Große; Dutch,
Karel de Grote; Danish/Norwegian/Swedish, Karl den Store; Italian, Carlo
Magno; Catalan, Carlemany; Bosnian, Croatian and Serbian, Karlo Veliki; Czech,
Karel Veliký; Slovak, Karol Veľký; Spanish, Carlomagno; Portuguese, Carlos
Magno; and various others.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Charles' achievements gave a new meaning to [his name](/wiki/Charles
"Charles"). In many European languages, the very word for "king" derives from
his name; e.g., [Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language"): _król_ ,
[Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainian_language "Ukrainian language"): король (korol'),
[Czech](/wiki/Czech_language "Czech language"): _král_ ,
[Slovak](/wiki/Slovak_language "Slovak language"): _kráľ_ ,
[Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): _király_ ,
[Lithuanian](/wiki/Lithuanian_language "Lithuanian language"): _karalius_ ,
[Latvian](/wiki/Latvian_language "Latvian language"): _karalis_ ,
[Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): король,
[Macedonian](/wiki/Macedonian_language "Macedonian language"): крал,
[Bulgarian](/wiki/Bulgarian_language "Bulgarian language"): крал,
[Romanian](/wiki/Romanian_language "Romanian language"): _crai_ ,
[Bosnian](/wiki/Bosnian_language "Bosnian language"): _kralj_ ,
[Serbian](/wiki/Serbian_language "Serbian language"): краљ/kralj,
[Croatian](/wiki/Croatian_language "Croatian language"): _kralj_ ,
[Turkish](/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language"): _kral_. This development
parallels that of the name of the Caesars in the original Roman Empire, which
became _kaiser_ and _czar_ , among others.[131]

## Beatification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=55
"Edit section: Beatification")]

Charlemagne was revered as a saint in the [Holy Roman
Empire](/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire "Holy Roman Empire") after the twelfth
century. The [Apostolic See](/wiki/Apostolic_See "Apostolic See") did not
recognise his invalid [canonisation](/wiki/Canonisation "Canonisation") by
[Antipope Paschal III](/wiki/Antipope_Paschal_III "Antipope Paschal III"),
done to gain the favour of [Frederick Barbarossa](/wiki/Frederick_Barbarossa
"Frederick Barbarossa") in 1165. The Apostolic See annulled all of Paschal's
ordinances at the [Third Lateran Council](/wiki/Third_Lateran_Council "Third
Lateran Council") in 1179.[132] He is not enumerated among the 28 saints named
"Charles" in the _[Roman Martyrology](/wiki/Roman_Martyrology "Roman
Martyrology")_.[133] His [beatification](/wiki/Beatification "Beatification")
has been acknowledged as _[cultus
confirmed](/wiki/Historical_process_of_beatification_and_canonization#Confirmation_of_cult
"Historical process of beatification and canonization")_ and is celebrated on
28 January.[132][134]

## Cultural uses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=56
"Edit section: Cultural uses")]

### Middle Ages[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=57
"Edit section: Middle Ages")]

Charlemagne had a sustained impact on European culture. The author of the
_[Visio Karoli Magni](/wiki/Visio_Karoli_Magni "Visio Karoli Magni")_ written
around 865 uses facts gathered apparently from Einhard and his own
observations on the decline of Charlemagne's family after the dissensions war
(840–43) as the basis for a visionary tale of Charles' meeting with a
prophetic spectre in a dream.

Charlemagne was a model [knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight") as one of the [Nine
Worthies](/wiki/Nine_Worthies "Nine Worthies") who enjoyed an important legacy
in European culture. One of the great medieval [literary
cycles](/wiki/Literary_cycle "Literary cycle"), the Charlemagne cycle or the
_[Matter of France](/wiki/Matter_of_France "Matter of France")_ , centres on
his deeds—the Emperor with the Flowing Beard of _[Roland](/wiki/Song_of_Roland
"Song of Roland")_ fame—and his historical commander of the border with
[Brittany](/wiki/Brittany "Brittany"), [Roland](/wiki/Roland "Roland"), and
the [paladins](/wiki/Paladin "Paladin") who are analogous to the knights of
the [Round Table](/wiki/Round_Table_\(Camelot\) "Round Table \(Camelot\)") of
[King Arthur](/wiki/King_Arthur "King Arthur")'s court. Their tales constitute
the first _[chansons de geste](/wiki/Chanson_de_geste "Chanson de geste")_. In
[the Divine Comedy](/wiki/The_Divine_Comedy "The Divine Comedy") the spirit of
Charlemagne appears to Dante in the Heaven of Mars, among the other "warriors
of the faith".[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Modern era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=58
"Edit section: Modern era")]

In 1867, an [equestrian statue](/wiki/Equestrian_statue "Equestrian statue")
of Charlemagne, was made by [Louis Jehotte](/wiki/Louis_Jehotte "Louis
Jehotte") and was inaugurated in 1868 on the Boulevard d'Avroy in
[Liège](/wiki/Li%C3%A8ge "Liège"). In the niches of the neo-roman
[pedestal](/wiki/Pedestal "Pedestal") are six statues of Charlemagne's
ancestors (Sainte Begge, Pépin de Herstal, Charles Martel, Bertrude, Pépin de
Landen and Pépin le Bref).

The city of Aachen has, since 1949, awarded an international prize (called the
_[Karlspreis](/wiki/Karlspreis "Karlspreis") der Stadt Aachen_) in honour of
Charlemagne. It is awarded annually to "personages of merit who have promoted
the idea of western unity by their political, economic and literary
endeavours."[135] Winners of the prize include [Richard von Coudenhove-
Kalergi](/wiki/Richard_von_Coudenhove-Kalergi "Richard von Coudenhove-
Kalergi"), the founder of the pan-European movement, [Alcide De
Gasperi](/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi "Alcide De Gasperi"), and [Winston
Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill").

In its national anthem, "[El Gran Carlemany](/wiki/El_Gran_Carlemany "El Gran
Carlemany")", the nation of [Andorra](/wiki/Andorra "Andorra") credits
Charlemagne with its independence.

In 1964, the young French singer [France Gall](/wiki/France_Gall "France
Gall") released the hit song "Sacré Charlemagne" in which the lyrics blame the
great king for imposing the burden of compulsory education on French children.

Charlemagne is quoted by Dr Henry Jones, Sr. in _[Indiana Jones and the Last
Crusade](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade "Indiana Jones and the Last
Crusade")_. After using his umbrella to induce a flock of seagulls to smash
through the glass cockpit of a pursuing German fighter plane, Henry Jones
remarks, "I suddenly remembered my Charlemagne: 'Let my armies be the rocks
and the trees and the birds in the sky'." Despite the quote's popularity since
the movie, there is no evidence that Charlemagne actually said this.[136]

_[The Economist](/wiki/The_Economist "The Economist")_ features a weekly
column entitled "Charlemagne", focusing generally on European affairs and,
more usually and specifically, on the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union
"European Union") and its politics.[137]

Actor and singer [Christopher Lee](/wiki/Christopher_Lee "Christopher Lee")'s
[symphonic metal](/wiki/Symphonic_metal "Symphonic metal") [concept
album](/wiki/Concept_album "Concept album") _[Charlemagne: By the Sword and
the Cross](/wiki/Charlemagne:_By_the_Sword_and_the_Cross "Charlemagne: By the
Sword and the Cross")_[138] and its [heavy metal](/wiki/Heavy_metal_music
"Heavy metal music") follow-up _[Charlemagne: The Omens of
Death](/wiki/Charlemagne:_The_Omens_of_Death "Charlemagne: The Omens of
Death")_ feature the events of Charlemagne's life.[139]

A 2010 episode of _[QI](/wiki/QI "QI")_ discussed the mathematics completed by
Mark Humphrys[140] that calculated that all modern Europeans are highly likely
to share Charlemagne as a common ancestor (see [most recent common
ancestor](/wiki/Most_recent_common_ancestor "Most recent common ancestor")).

In April 2014, on the occasion of the 1200th anniversary of Charlemagne's
death, public art _Mein Karl_ by [Ottmar Hörl](/wiki/Ottmar_H%C3%B6rl "Ottmar
Hörl") at Katschhof place was installed between city hall and the Aachen
cathedral, displaying 500 Charlemagne statues.[141]

## Books and
libraries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Charlemagne&action=edit&section=59 "Edit
section: Books and libraries")]

Charlemagne was a lover of books, sometimes having them read to him during
meals. He was thought to enjoy the works of St. Augustine.[142] His court
played a key role in producing books that taught elementary Latin and
different aspects of the church. It also played a part in creating a royal
library that contained in-depth works on language and Christian faith.[143]

Charlemagne encouraged clerics to translate Christian creeds and prayers into
their respective vernaculars as well to teach grammar and music. Due to the
increased interest of intellectual pursuits and the urging of their king, the
monks accomplished so much copying that almost every manuscript from that time
was preserved. At the same time, at the urging of their king, scholars were
producing more secular books on many subjects, including history, poetry, art,
music, law, theology, etc. Due to the increased number of titles, private
libraries flourished. These were mainly supported by aristocrats and churchmen
who could afford to sustain them. At Charlemagne's court, a library was
founded and a number of copies of books were produced, to be distributed by
Charlemagne.[144][131] Book production was completed slowly by hand, and took
place mainly in large monastic libraries. Books were so in demand during
Charlemagne's time that these libraries lent out some books, but only if that
borrower offered valuable collateral in return.[131] Most books, however, were
[held by chains](/wiki/Chained_library "Chained library") in order to
discourage theft. This made it difficult for multiple students to study one
title, but helped ensure the safety of the tomes.

Alcuin was a proponent of education and wrote thoughtfully on Christian
religion.[142] Considered the greatest scholar of his day, he became the
king's confidant and adviser. He brought his interest in libraries to the
king's court. He was also a tutor to the king and his sons, teaching them
liberal arts, theology and astrology.

  128. **Jump up ^** Charlemagne's biographer [Einhard](/wiki/Einhard "Einhard") (Vita Karoli Magni, ch. 20) calls her a "concubine" and [Paulus Diaconus](/wiki/Paulus_Diaconus "Paulus Diaconus") speaks of Pippin's birth "before legal marriage", whereas a letter by [Pope Stephen III](/wiki/Pope_Stephen_III "Pope Stephen III") refers to Charlemagne and his brother Carloman as being already married (to Himiltrude and [Gerberga](/wiki/Gerberga,_wife_of_Carloman_I "Gerberga, wife of Carloman I")), and advises them not to dismiss their wives. Historians have interpreted the information in different ways. Some, such as [Pierre Riché](/w/index.php?title=Pierre_Rich%C3%A9&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pierre Riché \(page does not exist\)") (_The Carolingians_ , p.86.), follow Einhard in describing Himiltrude as a concubine. Others, for example Dieter Hägemann (_Karl der Große. Herrscher des Abendlands_ , p. 82f.), consider Himiltrude a wife in the full sense. Still others subscribe to the idea that the relationship between the two was "something more than concubinage, less than marriage" and describe it as a [Friedelehe](/wiki/Friedelehe "Friedelehe"), a form of marriage unrecognised by the Church and easily dissolvable. Russell Chamberlin (_The Emperor Charlemagne_ , p. 61.), for instance, compared it with the English system of common-law marriage. This form of relationship is often seen in a conflict between Christian marriage and more flexible Germanic concepts.
  129. **Jump up ^** "By [Hildigard] Charlemagne had four sons and four daughters, according to Paul the Deacon: one son, the twin of Lewis, called Lothar, died as a baby and is not mentioned by Einhard; two daughters, Hildigard and Adelhaid, died as babies, so that Einhard appears to err in one of his names, unless there were really five daughters." Thorpe, Lewis, _Two Lives of Charlemagne_ , p.185
